{{redirect|Black Greeks|African American fraternities and sororities|National Pan-Hellenic Council}} {{Infobox ethnic group ||group=African immigrants to Greece
Άφρο-Έλληνες |image= |caption= |population= |langs=[[Greek language|Greek]], [[Niger–Congo languages]] |rels=predominantly [[Christianity]]; minority [[Islam]] |related-c=[[Ethnic groups of Africa|African people]] }} '''African immigrants to Greece''' are citizens or residents of [[Greece]] who have recent ancestors from nations in [[Africa]]. ==Overview== Some families of African descent, who came to Greece as [[Afro Turks|African slaves in the times of the Ottoman Empire]], still live in the village of [[Avato]] and are Sunni Muslims. Some of them lived before the [[Population exchange between Greece and Turkey]] also on the island of [[Crete]].Kenya-Crète-Istanbul: Biographie d'une famille d'esclaves, Paris, Librairie Özgül, 2006 {{ISBN|978-2-910901-02-8}} A number of African immigrants arrived in Greece in 1997. However, most came during the 2000s. The majority of the immigrants migrated from [[Biafra]], [[Nigeria]] and [[Senegal]]. Some of them also come from [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]], [[Zambia]] and [[Angola]]. Most live in the [[Patissia]] and [[Kypseli, Athens|Kypseli]] area in [[Athens]].[http://www.hitgreece.com/expats/immigrants-part3 Main ethnic groups of immigrants in Greece ] Some African immigrants and Greek citizens with ancestry from Africa report being the victim of racist harassment and assaults from suspected far-right Greek [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] party members.http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/12/greece-racist-attacks_n_2116302.html{{Cite web|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2013/05/29/black-panthers-will-fight-golden-dawn/|title=Black Panthers Will Fight Golden Dawn {{!}} GreekReporter.com|website=greece.greekreporter.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-31}} ==Notable African-Greeks== *[[Giannis Antetokounmpo]] - [[NBA]] professional basketball player *[[Thanasis Antetokounmpo]] - professional basketball player *[[Daniel Batista Lima]] – soccer player *[[Nestoras Kommatos]] – professional basketball player *[[Sofoklis Schortsanitis]] – professional basketball player *[[Isaias Matiaba]] – singer *[[Nery Mantey Niangkouara]] – former swimmer *[[Tyler Dorsey]] – American-Greek [[NBA]] basketball player *[[Emmanouil Karalis]] - professional pole vaulter *[[Neil Matopalin]] professional pole vaulter ==See also== *[[African immigration to Europe]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.academia.edu/2579778/IMMIGRATION_TO_GREECE_AN_OVERVIEW_OF_IMMIGRATION_POLICIES_LEGISLATION_AND_SPORADIC_ATTEMPTS_AT_SOCIAL_INCLUSION_OF_IMMIGRANTS Immigration to Greece] {{Immigration from Africa}} [[Category:African diaspora in Europe]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Greece]] [[Category:Greek people of African descent| ]] [[Category:People of African descent|Greece]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2017}} The '''Bhil Kataria''' are a sub-division of the [[Bhil]] community found in the state of [[Rajasthan]] in [[India]]. They are known as Kataria Bhil because they inhabit the Kataria region of Rajasthan. It is an area that covers parts of the districts of [[Udaipur District|Udaipur]], [[Dungarpur]] and [[Banswara District|Banswara]].<ref name="autogenerated159">People of India Rajasthan Volume XXXVIII Part One edited by B.K Lavania, D. K Samanta, S K Mandal & N.N Vyas pages 159 to 164 Popular Prakashan</ref>
Their clans are known as ''atak'', and there are said to be at least eighty four ataks. The Kataria are a community of small and medium-sized farmers. Most of their settlements are exclusively Kataria, and each of them contains an informal caste association. This acts as an instrument of social control, punishing those who transgress community norms. They are entirely [[Hindu]] and unlike other [[Bhil]] groups do not have non Hindu tribal deities. The Kataria speak the [[Bagri language|Bagri]] dialect of [[Rajasthani language|Rajasthani]].<ref name="autogenerated159"/>
== Marriage ==
Like other Bhil groups, they are [[endogamous]]. They have a greater level of distance from assimilation by [[Brahminical]] [[Sanskritisation]].
== See also == * [[Bhil Gametia]] * [[Bhil Mama]] * Kataria
==References==
{{reflist}} {{Bhil Clans}}
[[Category:Bhil]] [[Category:Scheduled Tribes of Rajasthan]]

{{MEDREF|date=December 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox medical condition | Name = Cannabis use disorder | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|F|12||f|10}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|304.3}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = }}
'''Cannabis use disorder''' ('''CUD'''), also known as '''cannabis addiction''' or '''marijuana addiction''', is defined in the fifth revision of the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]] ([[DSM-5]]) and [[ICD-10]] published by [[World Health Organization]] as the continued use of cannabis despite clinically significant impairment, ranging from mild to severe.<ref name=nida>{{citation|last=National Institute on Drug Abuse|title=The Science of Drug Abuse and Addiction: The Basics|url=https://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/media-guide/science-drug-abuse-addiction-basics|year=2014}}</ref><!-- <ref name=Gordon2013>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gordon AJ, Conley JW, Gordon JM |title=Medical consequences of marijuana use: a review of current literature |journal=Curr Psychiatry Rep |volume=15 |issue=12 |pages=419 |date=December 2013 |pmid=24234874 |doi=10.1007/s11920-013-0419-7 |type=Review}}</ref> -->
== Signs and symptoms ==
Marijuana use and abuse has symptoms that affect behavior, physical, cognitive, and psychosocial aspects of a person's life. Symptoms include agitation, bloodshot eyes, challenges in problem solving, and paranoia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cannabis Symptoms|url=http://www.timberlineknolls.com/drug-addiction/marijuana/signs-effects/|website=Timberline Knolls|accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref>
Cannabis use is [[Long-term effects of cannabis#Mental health|associated with comorbid mental health problems]], such as mood and anxiety disorders, and discontinuing cannabis use is difficult for some users.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> Psychiatric comorbidities are often present in dependent cannabis users including a range of personality disorders.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://bv8ja7kw5x.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Cannabis%3A+Use+and+dependence&rft.jtitle=Presse+m%C3%A9dicale+%28Paris%2C+France+%3A+1983%29&rft.au=Dervaux%2C+Alain&rft.au=Laqueille%2C+Xavier&rft.date=2012-12-01&rft.issn=0755-4982&rft.volume=41&rft.issue=12%20Pt%201&rft.spage=1233&rft_id=info:pmid/23040955&rft.externalDocID=23040955&paramdict=en-AU|title = Cannabis: Use and dependence|last = Dervaux|first = Alain|date = December 2012|journal = La Presse Médicale|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
The use of cannabis at a young age such as the teenage years, can have serious impacts on depression and anxiety in youth and later in life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ncpic.org.au/professionals/publications/factsheets/cannabis-and-young-people/|title=Cannabis and young people {{!}} NCPIC|last=NCPIC|website=ncpic.org.au|access-date=2016-09-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309211757/https://ncpic.org.au/professionals/publications/factsheets/cannabis-and-young-people/#|archive-date=9 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> There is evidence that cannabis use during adolescence, at a time when the brain is still developing, may have deleterious effects on neural development and later cognitive functioning.<ref name=McLaren/> The brain is not completely developed until a person reaches the age range of 22-27. Excessive use of marijuana can cause harm to this development.<ref name="Cannabis use and later life outcomes">{{cite web|title=Excessive use of Cannabis|url=https://www.cdc.gov/marijuana/factsheets/teens.htm|website=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref>. Based on an annual survey data 7 percent of high school seniors that smoke daily function at a lower rate in school than students that do not.<ref>{{cite web|last1=E.B.|first1=Robertson|title=Information on Cannabis Addiction|url=https://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/principles-adolescent-substance-use-disorder-treatment-research-based-guide/references|website=National Institute on Drug Abuse|accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref> The sedating and [[anxiolytic]] properties of [[THC]] in some users might make the use of cannabis an attempt to self-medicate [[personality disorder|personality]] or [[psychiatric disorders]].<ref name=Mcd/>
===Dependency=== Prolonged marijuana use produces both [[pharmacokinetic]] changes (how the drug is absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and excreted) and [[pharmacodynamic]] changes (how the drug interacts with target cells) to the body. These changes require the user to consume higher doses of the drug to achieve a common desirable effect (known as a higher tolerance), reinforcing the body's metabolic systems for eliminating the drug more efficiently<ref name="joy">{{Cite book| title=Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing The Science Base |author1=J.E. Joy |author2=S. J. Watson, Jr. |author3=J.A. Benson, Jr | location=Washington, D.C.| publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences Press]] | year=1999|url=http://books.nap.edu/html/marimed/| isbn=0-585-05800-8}}</ref> and further downregulating cannabinoid receptors in the brain.<ref name="HirvonenGoodwin2011">{{cite journal|last1=Hirvonen|first1=J|last2=Goodwin|first2=R S|last3=Li|first3=C-T|last4=Terry|first4=G E|last5=Zoghbi|first5=S S|last6=Morse|first6=C|last7=Pike|first7=V W|last8=Volkow|first8=N D|last9=Huestis|first9=M A|last10=Innis|first10=R B|title=Reversible and regionally selective downregulation of brain cannabinoid CB1 receptors in chronic daily cannabis smokers|journal=Molecular Psychiatry|volume=17|issue=6|year=2011|pages=642–649|issn=1359-4184|doi=10.1038/mp.2011.82|pmid=21747398|pmc=3223558}}</ref> These effects compound themselves in that the chronic user must consume more frequently to overcome the accelerated clearance, and higher doses to overcome the blunted response to receptor activation.
Cannabis users have shown decreased reactivity to dopamine, suggesting a possible link to a dampening of the reward system of the brain and an increase in negative emotionality and addiction severity.<ref name="Madras2014">{{cite journal|last1=Madras|first1=B. K.|title=Dopamine challenge reveals neuroadaptive changes in marijuana abusers|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=111|issue=33|year=2014|pages=11915–11916|issn=0027-8424|doi=10.1073/pnas.1412314111|pmid=25114244|pmc=4143049}}</ref>
Cannabis users can develop tolerance to the effects of [[THC]]. Tolerance to the behavioral and psychological effects of THC has been demonstrated in adolescent humans and animals.<ref name=gonzalez>{{cite journal|last1=Gonzalez|first1=S|last2=Cebeira|first2=M|last3=Fernandez-Ruiz|first3=J|title=Cannabinoid tolerance and dependence: A review of studies in laboratory animals|journal=Pharmacology Biochemistry and Behavior|date=June 2005|volume=81|issue=2|pages=300–318|doi=10.1016/j.pbb.2005.01.028}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maldonado|first1=R.|last2=Berrendero|first2=F.|last3=Ozaita|first3=A.|last4=Robledo|first4=P.|title=Neurochemical basis of cannabis addiction|journal=Neuroscience|date=May 2011|volume=181|pages=1–17|doi=10.1016/j.neuroscience.2011.02.035}}</ref> The mechanisms that create this tolerance to THC are thought to involve changes in cannabinoid receptor function.<ref name=gonzalez/>
According to the [[National Cannabis Prevention and Information Centre]] in Australia, a sign of cannabis dependence is that an individual spends noticeably more time than the average recreational user recovering from the use of or obtaining cannabis. For some, using cannabis becomes a substantial and disruptive part of an individual's life and he or she may exhibit difficulties in meeting personal obligations or participating in important life activities, preferring to use cannabis instead. People who are cannabis dependent have the inability to stop or decrease using cannabis on their own.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehealingclinic.org/alcohol-vs-cannabis-2015-infographic/|title=Alcohol vs Cannabis 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=National Cannabis Prevention and Information|access-date=|accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref>
Marijuana addiction is more common among heavy users. Marijuana use can lead to increased [[drug tolerance|tolerance]]<ref name=Borgelt2013/><ref name=Sewell2009>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sewell RA, Poling J, Sofuoglu M |title=The effect of cannabis compared with alcohol on driving |journal=Am J Addict |volume=18 |issue=3 |pages=185–93 |year=2009 |pmid=19340636 |pmc=2722956 |doi=10.1080/10550490902786934 |type=Review}}</ref> and, in some users, withdrawal symptoms when trying to stop.<ref name=Gordon2013>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gordon AJ, Conley JW, Gordon JM |title=Medical consequences of marijuana use: a review of current literature |journal=Curr Psychiatry Rep |volume=15 |issue=12 |pages=419 |date=December 2013 |pmid=24234874 |doi=10.1007/s11920-013-0419-7 |type=Review}}</ref><ref name=Danovitch2012/>
===Withdrawal=== Cannabis withdrawal symptoms can occur in one half of patients in treatment for cannabis use disorders. These symptoms include dysphoria (anxiety, irritability, depression, restlessness), disturbed sleep, gastrointestinal symptoms, and decreased appetite. Most symptoms begin during the first week of abstinence and resolve after a few weeks.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> The withdrawal symptoms are usually not severe, even after heavy use.<ref>http://www.druglibrary.org/SCHAFFER/library/studies/ledain/tolerance_and_dependence.htm</ref>
== Cause == Cannabis addiction is often due to prolonged and increasing use of the drug. Increasing the strength of the cannabis taken and an increasing use of more effective methods of delivery often increase the progression of cannabis dependency. It can also be caused by being prone to becoming addicted to substances, which can either be genetically or environmentally acquired.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://bjp.rcpsych.org/content/182/4/330|title = Adolescent precursors of cannabis addiction: Findings from the Victorian Adolescent Health Cohort Study|last = Coffey1, Carlin2, Lynskey3, Li4, Patton5|first = Carolyn1, John B.2, Michael3, Ning4, George C.5|date = 1 April 2003|journal = The British Journal of Psychiatry|doi = 10.1192/bjp.182.4.330|pmid = |access-date = 17 April 2015|volume=182|pages=330–336}}</ref>
=== Risk factors === Certain factors are considered to heighten the risk of developing cannabis dependence and longitudinal studies over a number of years have enabled researchers to track aspects of social and psychological development concurrently with cannabis use. Increasing evidence is being shown for the elevation of associated problems by the frequency and age at which cannabis is used, with young and frequent users being at most risk.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/drugfacts/marijuana | title=DrugFacts: Marijuana | publisher=National Institute on Drug Abuse | accessdate=20 July 2015}}</ref>
The main factors in Australia, for example, related to a heightened risk for developing problems with cannabis use include frequent use at a young age; personal maladjustment; emotional distress; poor parenting; school drop-out; affiliation with drug-using peers; moving away from home at an early age; daily cigarette smoking; and ready access to cannabis. The researchers concluded there is emerging evidence that positive experiences to early cannabis use are a significant predictor of late dependence and that genetic predisposition plays a role in the development of problematic use.<ref name=Copeland2004/>
=== High risk groups ===
A number of groups have been identified as being at greater risk of developing cannabis dependence and, in Australia, for example, have been found to include adolescent populations, [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal]] and [[Torres Strait Islanders]] and people suffering from mental health conditions.<ref name=McLaren>McLaren, J, Mattick, R P., ''Cannabis in Australia Use, supply, harms, and responses'' Monograph series No. 57 Report prepared for: Drug Strategy Branch Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing. National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre University of New South Wales, Australia.</ref>
==== Adolescents ====
Young people are at greater risk of developing cannabis dependency because of the association between early initiation into substance use and subsequent problems such as dependence, and the risks associated with using cannabis at a developmentally vulnerable age.<ref name=McLaren/>
== Diagnosis == {{expand section|date=May 2018}} Cannabis use disorder is recognized in the fifth version of the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]]'' ([[DSM-5]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dsm5.org/ProposedRevisions/Pages/proposedrevision.aspx?rid=39# |title=Proposed Revision | APA DSM-5 |publisher=Dsm5.org |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}}</ref> which added cannabis withdrawal as a new condition.<ref name="highlights">{{cite web|url=https://rogershospital.org/blog/dsm-5-now-categorizes-substance-use-disorders-single-continuum|title=DSM-5 Now Categorizes Substance Use Disorder in a Single Continuum|last=|first=|date=17 May 2013|website=|publisher=[[American Psychiatric Association]]|format=PDF|access-date=|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref>
Some healthcare facilities have been known to diagnose patients with Cannabis Use Disorder, even when the patient does not exhibit or experience any of the criteria for the disorder, simply on the basis that the patient uses cannabis in any manner. Patients receiving this false diagnosis have, in some cases, been denied insurance benefits and employment as a result of the false diagnosis, leaving the healthcare facilities vulnerable to legal action.
== Treatment== Clinicians differentiate between casual users who have difficulty with drug screens, and daily heavy users, to a chronic user who uses multiple times a day.<ref name=Mcd>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JJk52UeE6hYC& Clinical Textbook of Addictive Disorders], Marijuana, [[David McDowell]], page 169, Published by [[Guilford Press]], 2005 {{ISBN|1-59385-174-X}}.</ref>
=== Psychological ===
[[Psychological intervention]] includes [[cognitive behavioral therapy]] (CBT), [[motivational enhancement therapy]] (MET), [[contingency management]] (CM), supportive-expressive psychotherapy (SEP), family and systems interventions, and [[twelve-step program]]s.<ref name=Danovitch2012/>
Evaluations of [[Marijuana Anonymous]] programs, modelled on the 12-step lines of [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] and [[Narcotics Anonymous]], have shown small beneficial effects for general drug use reduction.{{mcn|date=December 2013}} In 2006, the Wisconsin Initiative to Promote Healthy Lifestyles implemented a program that helps primary care physicians identify and address marijuana use problems in patients.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality |url=https://innovations.ahrq.gov/profiles/support-collaborative-primary-care-practices-identify-and-address-behavioral-health-issues |title=With Support From Collaborative, Primary Care Practices Identify and Address Behavioral Health Issues, Reducing Binge Drinking, Marijuana Use, and Depression Symptoms |date=2013-05-08 |accessdate=2013-05-10}}</ref>
=== Barriers to treatment ===
Research that looks at barriers to cannabis treatment frequently cites a lack of interest in treatment, lack of motivation and knowledge of treatment facilities, an overall lack of facilities, costs associated with treatment, difficulty meeting program eligibility criteria and transport difficulties.<ref name="autogenerated367">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/09687630600761444 | last1 = Treloar | first1 = C. | last2 = Holt | first2 = M. | year = 2006 | title = Deficit models and divergent philosophies: Service providers' perspectives on barriers and incentives to drug treatment | url = | journal = Drugs: Education prevention and policy | volume = 13 | issue = 4| pages = 367–382 }}</ref><ref>Treloar, C., Abelson, J., Cao, W., Brener, L., Kippax, S., Schultz, L., Schultz, M., & Bath, N. (2004). ''Barriers and incentives to treatment for illicit drug users''(Monograph Series 53). Canberra: Department of Health and Ageing, National Drug Strategy.</ref><ref>Gates, P., Taplin, S., Copeland, J., swift, W., Martin G. (2008) ''Barriers and Facilitators to Cannabis Treatment''National Cannabis Prevention and Information Centre, University of New South Wales, Sydney</ref>
===Treatment for dependency=== In the US, {{asof|2013|lc=yes}}, cannabis is the most commonly identified illicit substance used by people admitted to treatment facilities.<ref name=Borgelt2013>{{cite journal |vauthors=Borgelt LM, Franson KL, Nussbaum AM, Wang GS |title=The pharmacologic and clinical effects of medical cannabis |journal=Pharmacotherapy |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=195–209 |date=February 2013 |pmid=23386598 |doi=10.1002/phar.1187 |type=Review}}</ref> Demand for treatment for cannabis use disorder increased internationally between 1995 and 2002.<ref>Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Office of Applied Studies. (2003). ''Emergency department trends from the drug abuse warning network, final estimates 1995–2002'', DAWN Series: D-24, DHHS Publication No. (SMA) 03-3780.</ref> In the United States, the average adult who seeks treatment has consumed cannabis for over 10 years almost daily and has attempted to quit six or more times.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Marijuana Dependence and Its Treatment|journal = Addiction Science & Clinical Practice|date=December 2007|issn = 1940-0632|pmc = 2797098|pmid = 18292704|pages = 4–16|volume = 4|issue = 1|first = Alan J.|last = Budney|first2 = Roger|last2 = Roffman|first3 = Robert S.|last3 = Stephens|first4 = Denise|last4 = Walker|doi=10.1151/ascp07414}}</ref>
No medications have been found effective for cannabis dependence as of 2014,<ref name=Cochrane2014>{{cite journal|last1=Marshall|first1=K|last2=Gowing|first2=L|last3=Ali|first3=R|last4=Le Foll|first4=B|title=Pharmacotherapies for cannabis dependence.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=17 December 2014|volume=12|pages=CD008940|pmid=25515775|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD008940.pub2|pmc=4297244}}</ref> but psychotherapeutic models hold promise.<ref name=Danovitch2012/>
Treatment options for cannabis dependence are far fewer than for opiate or alcohol dependence. Most treatment falls into the categories of psychological or psychotherapeutic, intervention, pharmacological intervention or treatment through peer support and environmental approaches.<ref name=Copeland2004>Copeland, J, Gerber, S, Swift, W. ''Evidence-based answers to cannabis questions a review of the literature''National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre University of New South Wales A report prepared for the Australian National Council on Drugs, December 2004</ref> Screening and brief intervention sessions can be given in a variety of settings, particularly at doctor's surgeries, which is of importance as most cannabis users seeking help will do so from their general practitioner rather than a drug treatment service agency.<ref>Degenhardt, L., Hall, W. and Lynskey, M. (2000a) ''Cannabis use and mental health among Australian adults: Findings from the National Survey of Mental Health and Well-being''. NDARC Technical Report No. 98 Sydney, National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre, University of New South Wales.</ref>
The most commonly accessed forms of treatment in Australia are 12-step programmes, physicians, rehabilitation programmes, and detox services, with inpatient and outpatient services equally accessed.<ref name=Copeland2009>{{cite journal |vauthors=Copeland J, Swift W |title=Cannabis use disorder: epidemiology and management |journal=Int Rev Psychiatry |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages=96–103 |date=April 2009 |pmid=19367503 |doi=10.1080/09540260902782745|type=Review}}</ref> In the EU approximately 20% of all primary admissions and 29% of all new drug clients in 2005, had primary cannabis problems. And in all countries that reported data between 1999–2005 the number of people seeking treatment for cannabis use increased.<ref>EMCDDA (2007). ''Annual report 2007: The state of the drugs problem in Europe''. Luxembourg: Office for Official Publications of the European Communities</ref>
==== Medication ==== As of 2012, there is no medication that has been proven effective for treating cannabis use disorder; research is focused on three treatment approaches: agonist substitution, antagonist, and modulation of other neurotransmitter systems.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> [[Dronabinol]] is an agonist that is legally available; in some cases and trials, it reduced symptoms of withdrawal and reduced cannabis use.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> [[Entacapone]] was well-tolerated and decreased cannabis cravings in a trial on a small number of patients.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> [[Acetylcysteine]] (NAC) decreased cannabis use and craving in a trial.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> [[Atomoxetine]] in a small study showed no significant change in cannabis use, and most patients experienced adverse events.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> [[Buspirone]] shows promise as a treatment for dependence; trials show it reducing cravings, irritability and depression.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> [[Divalproex]] in a small study was poorly tolerated and did not show a significant reduction in cannabis use among subjects.<ref name=Danovitch2012/>
==Epidemiology== [[Cannabis (drug)|Cannabis]] is one of the most widely used drugs in the world. In the United States, 49% of people have used cannabis.<ref>http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/04/14/6-facts-about-marijuana/</ref> an estimated 9% of those who use cannabis develop dependence.<ref name=Budney2007>{{cite journal|last1=Budney|first1=AJ|last2=Roffman|first2=R|last3=Stephens|first3=RS|last4=Walker|first4=D|title=Marijuana dependence and its treatment.|journal=Addiction science & clinical practice|date=Dec 2007|volume=4|issue=1|pages=4–16|pmid=18292704|doi=10.1151/ascp07414|pmc=2797098}}</ref><ref name=Cochrane2014/> 34.8% of Australians aged 14 years and over have used cannabis one or more times in their life.<ref name=DrugInfoAu>{{Cite web|url = http://www.druginfo.adf.org.au/topics/quick-statistics#cannabis|title = Drug Info|date = |accessdate = |website = Australian Drug Foundation|publisher = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110425032922/http://www.druginfo.adf.org.au/topics/quick-statistics#cannabis#cannabis|archive-date = 25 April 2011|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}}</ref> In the United States, 42% have used cannabis.<ref name=Gordon2013/> In the U.S., cannabis is the most commonly identified illicit substance used by people admitted to treatment facilities.<ref name=Danovitch2012/> Most of these people were referred there by the criminal justice system. 16% of admittees either went on their own, or were referred by family or friends.<ref name=TEDS2011>{{cite web|title=Treatment Episode Data Set (TEDS)2001 – 2011. National Admissions to Substance Abuse Treatment Services|url=http://archive.samhsa.gov/data/2k13/TEDS2011/TEDS2011N.pdf|website=samhsa.gov|publisher=Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration|accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref>
There is a high prevalence of cannabis use in the [[United States|US]].<ref name=Danovitch2012>{{cite journal |vauthors=Danovitch I, Gorelick DA |title=State of the art treatments for cannabis dependence |journal=Psychiatr. Clin. North Am. |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=309–26 |date=June 2012 |pmid=22640758 |pmc=3371269 |doi=10.1016/j.psc.2012.03.003 |type=Review}}</ref> Cannabis dependence develops in 9% users, significantly less than that of heroin, cocaine, alcohol, and prescribed [[anxiolytics]],<ref name="Wilkie2016">{{cite journal |vauthors=Wilkie G, Sakr B, Rizack T |title=Medical Marijuana Use in Oncology: A Review |journal=JAMA Oncology |date=March 2016 |pmid=26986677 |doi=10.1001/jamaoncol.2016.0155}}</ref> but slightly higher than that for [[psilocybin]], [[mescaline]], or [[LSD]].<ref name=Budney2007/> Of those who use cannabis daily, 10–20% develop dependence.<ref name=Borgelt2013/>
== Research ==
[[Columbia University]], in collaboration with the [[National Institute on Drug Abuse]] (NIDA), is undertaking a clinical trial that looks at the effects of combined medication on cannabis dependency, to see if [[lofexidine]] in combination with [[dronabinol]] is superior to placebo in achieving abstinence, reducing cannabis use and reducing withdrawal in cannabis-dependent patients seeking treatment for their marijuana use.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01020019 |title=US National Institute of Health |publisher=Clinicaltrials.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}}</ref> Men and women between the ages of 18–60 who met DSM-IV criteria for current marijuana dependence were enrolled in a 12-week trial that started in January 2010.
Georgotas & Zeidenberg (1979) conducted an experiment where they gave an average daily dose of 210 mg of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the ingredient in cannabis which is responsible for its psychological effects,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.livescience.com/24553-what-is-thc.html|title = Live Science|date = 2015|accessdate = 17 April 2015|website = What is THC (tetrahydrocannabinol)?|publisher = |last = Bradford|first = Alina}}</ref> to a group of volunteers over a 4-week period. After the test ended, the subjects were found to be "irritable, uncooperative, resistant and at times hostile," and many of the patients experienced insomnia. These effects were likely due to withdrawal from the drug and lasted about 3 weeks after the experiment.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://bjp.rcpsych.org/content/178/2/116|title = Psychiatric effects of cannabis|last = Johns|first = Andrew|date = 1 February 2001|journal = The British Journal of Psychiatry|doi = 10.1192/bjp.178.2.116|pmid = |access-date = 17 April 2015|volume=178|pages=116–122}}</ref>
A 2014 [[Cochrane Collaboration]] review found insufficient data to evaluate the effectiveness of [[gabapentin]] and [[acetylcysteine]] in the treatment of cannabis dependence and that it warrants further investigation.<ref name=Cochrane2014/>
== See also ==
* [[La Guardia Committee]], the first in depth study into the effects of cannabis. * [[Medical cannabis]]

[[File:Capsule hotel.jpg|thumb|300px|Capsules in Tokyo]] [[File:Capsule interior.jpg|thumb|Capsule interior]] [[File:CapsuleHotel.jpg|thumb|Capsules in Osaka]] [[File:CapsuleHotelCapsule.jpg|thumb|upright|The box in the upper left foreground is the TV, which is controlled via the panel in the left background. This panel also controls the light and the air conditioning. On the right wall is a mirror and the air conditioning inlet in the top corner.]] A {{nihongo|'''capsule hotel'''|カプセルホテル|kapuseru hoteru}}, also known as a '''pod hotel''', is a type of [[hotel]] developed in [[Japan]] that features a large number of extremely small "rooms" (capsules) intended to provide cheap, basic overnight accommodation for guests who do not require or who cannot afford the services offered by more conventional hotels.
==Description== The guest room is a modular plastic or [[fiberglass]] block roughly {{Convert|2|by|1|by|1.25|m|ftin|abbr=on}}. Facilities differ, but most include a television, an electronic console, and [[wireless internet]] connection. The capsules are stacked side-by-side, two units high, with steps providing access to the second level rooms, leading to comparisons to corpse drawers in a [[morgue]].<ref>[http://weburbanist.com/2011/01/31/13-of-japans-most-stylish-strange-hotels/ Japan's most stylish/strange hotels]</ref> The open end of the capsule can be closed, for privacy, with a curtain or a fiberglass door. Luggage is stored in a locker and washrooms are communal. Guests are asked not to smoke or eat in the capsules.<ref>Solomon, Leonard (1997). ''Japan in a Nutshell''. Top Hat Press, 115–166. {{ISBN|0-912509-06-6}}.</ref> Some hotels also provide restaurants (or at least [[vending machine]]s), pools, and other entertainment facilities.<ref>Schreiber, Mark (January 16, 2001). "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20110116x2.html Back to the future of a 'hotel for 2001']", ''[[The Japan Times]]'', pp. 7–8.</ref> Capsule hotels vary in size, from fifty or so capsules to 700, and they are used primarily by men.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e2025.html#capsule |title=Accommodation in Japan |publisher=Japan-guide.com |date=2012-11-11 |accessdate=2012-11-30}}</ref> Some capsule hotels offer separate sections for male and female guests. Clothes and shoes can sometimes be exchanged for a ''[[yukata]]'' and slippers on entry. A towel may also be provided.
The benefit of these hotels is convenience and low price, usually around ¥2000–4000 (USD {{To USD|2000|JPN|round=yes}}–{{To USD|4000|JPN|round=yes}}) a night. They provide an alternative for those who (especially on weeknights) may be too [[drunk]] to return home safely, or too embarrassed to face their spouses.<ref>Wardell, Steven (October 1994). "Capsule cure". ''[[Atlantic Monthly]]''. '''274''' (4):42–47.</ref> With continued [[Japanese Recession|recession in Japan]], as of early 2010, more and more guests – roughly 30% at the Capsule Hotel Shinjuku 510 in [[Tokyo]] – were unemployed or [[underemployment|underemployed]] who had become homeless during the crisis and were temporarily renting capsules by the month.<ref>Tabuchi, Hiroko. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/02/business/global/02capsule.html "For Some in Japan, Home Is a Tiny Plastic Bunk"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 2010-01-01. Retrieved on 2010-01-18.</ref> This style of hotel has not gained wide popularity outside Japan, although Western variants known as "pod hotels"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fodors.com/news/story-2357.html|title=Pod Hotels: Small, Stylish, and Cheap|author=Fodor's Editors|publisher=Fodors.com|date=December 31, 2007|accessdate=March 9, 2012}}</ref> have been developed, with larger accommodations and often private baths.
==History== The first capsule hotel in the world was the Capsule Inn Osaka, designed by [[Kisho Kurokawa]] and located in the [[Umeda]] district of [[Osaka]], Japan. It opened in 1979.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://capsulehotel-inn-osaka.com/|title= Capsule Inn Osaka|publisher= |location= |language= Japanese|accessdate= 24 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kotobuki.co.jp/company/history.html |title=Kotobuki Corporation History |publisher=Kotobuki Corporation |location= |language=Japanese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724211653/http://www.kotobuki.co.jp/company/history.html |archivedate=2010-07-24 |accessdate=24 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 2012, China opened its first capsule hotel in [[Xi'an]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnngo.com/shanghai/life/chinas-first-capsule-hotel-opened-xian-543024 |title=China's first capsule hotel opens in Xi'an |publisher= CNN Travel |website=Cnngo.com |date=2012-05-14 |accessdate=2012-11-30}}</ref>
In 2014, the first European capsule hotel opened in [[Belgium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/lifestyle/trend-alert-belgium-opens-europe-s-first-capsule-hotel-1.2025681|title=Trend alert: Belgium opens Europe's first capsule hotel |publisher=CTV News |date=2014-09-26 |accessdate=2016-06-10}}</ref>
In 2015, Iceland opened the first capsule hostel in Reykjavik.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2015/12/06/svefnhylki_komin_a_hotelmarkadinn/|title=Svefnhylki komin á hótelmarkaðinn|access-date=2016-06-25}}</ref>
In 2015, a capsule hotel was opened at Terminal 3 of the [[Ninoy Aquino International Airport]] in [[Metro Manila]], the [[Philippines]], for passengers in transit.{{cn|date=August 2018}}
In January 2017, the first capsule hotel opened in [[Hong Kong]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perspectiveglobal.com/interiors/sleeep-hong-kongs-first-capsule-hotel/|title=Sleep{{snd}}Hong Kong's first capsule hotel |publisher=Perspective Global |date=2017-01-27 |accessdate=2017-02-15}}</ref>
On September 17, 2017, a capsule hotel in [[Indonesia]] was opened in [[Surabaya]], [[East Java]]. The hotel is called Tab Capsule.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://jatim.tribunnews.com/2017/09/17/kamar-kapsul-tab-hotel-kini-hadir-di-kayoon-surabaya-cukup-bayar-segini-sudah-dekat-pusat-kota |title=Kamar Kapsul TAB Hotel Kini Hadir di Kayoon Surabaya, Cukup Bayar Segini Sudah Dekat Pusat Kota! |publisher=Tribun Jatim |date=17 September 2017 |accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref>
In August 2018, a capsule hotel with 120 rooms is opened at [[Soekarno–Hatta International Airport Terminal 3]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://en.tempo.co/read/news/2018/08/08/056920640/Soekarno-Hatta-Airports-Capsule-Hotel-Can-be-Booked-Online|title= Soekarno Hatta Airport`s Capsule Hotel Can be Booked Online|newspaper=Tempo|accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref>
The first capsule hotel in [[India]] was opened on 1 March 2017 in [[Andheri]], [[Mumbai]]. The hotel, called [[Urbanpod]], contains 140 units with an individual area of between 50 square feet and 90 sq ft.<ref>{{cite web|title=With 50 sq ft, India's first pod hotel opens in Mumbai |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/money/report-with-50-sq-ft-india-s-first-pod-hotel-opens-in-mumbai-2340783|website=dna|accessdate=3 March 2017|date=3 March 2017}}</ref>
The first capsule hotel in Mexico was opened August 2017 at Mexico City Airport Terminal 1; the hotel is called Izzzleep.{{cn|date=August 2018}}
== See also == {{portal|Housing}} * [[Sleepbox]] * [[Transit hotel]] * [[Flophouse]]

{{Infobox film | name = Charge of the Lancers | image = File:Charge of the Lancers.jpg | caption = | director = [[William Castle]] | producer = [[Sam Katzman]] | writer = | based on = | starring = | music = | cinematography = [[Henry Freulich]] | editing = Henry Batista | studio = Columbia Pictures | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = February 1954 | runtime = 73 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''Charge of the Lancers''''' is a 1954 American [[adventure film]] directed by [[William Castle]] and starring [[Paulette Goddard]], [[Jean-Pierre Aumont]] and [[Richard Wyler]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/29122|title=Charge of the Lancers (1953)|publisher=}}</ref> During the [[Crimean War]], a French officer attached to the British forces takes part in trials for a secret weapon and becomes entangled with a [[Romani people|Gypsy]] woman.
==Cast== * [[Paulette Goddard]] - Tanya * [[Jean-Pierre Aumont]] - Captain Eric Evoir * [[Richard Wyler]] - Major Bruce Lindsey * [[Karin Booth]] - Maria Sand * [[Charles Irwin (actor)|Charles Irwin]] - Tom Daugherty * [[Ben Astar]] - General Inderman * [[Lester Matthews]] - General Stanhope * [[Gregory Gaye]] - Corporal Bonikoff * [[Ivan Triesault]] - Doctor Manus * [[Louis Merrill]] - Colonel Zeansky * [[Tony Roux]] - Asa * [[Fernanda Eliscu]] - Keta

revision.text:
[[Image:Cvmrr-newlayout1.jpg|thumb|right|Part of the passenger station throat on the new layout]]
'''Cherry Valley O Scale''' is a [[not for profit|not-for-profit]] club dedicated to the promotion of 2-rail [[O scale|O-scale]] ([[1:48 scale|1:48]]) [[Rail transport modelling|model railroading]],<ref name="aap1">"Choo Choo", ''All Around Pennsauken'', December 2012</ref> located in [[Merchantville, New Jersey|Merchantville]], [[New Jersey]], United States, in the basement/[[undercroft]] of the Grace Episcopal Church.<ref name="Courpo1">"Holiday Open House: Cherry Valley Train Club", ''Camden NJ Courier-Post'', December 30, 2012</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.merchantville.com/merchantville/groups/374-model-railroad-club-open-house-# |title=Merchantville Online: Model Railroad Club Open House |access-date=2011-08-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927033252/http://www.merchantville.com/merchantville/groups/374-model-railroad-club-open-house-# |archive-date=2011-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="Obsrv1">"Model Railroad Open House", ''Merchantville Observer'', November 12, 2012</ref>
==History== [[Image:Cvmrr-oldlayout.jpg|thumb|left|Control panel from the old layout.]]
The club was started in March 1962,<ref name="Courpo2">Arthur M McGuire, "Model Railroad Runs Like Real", ''Camden NJ Courier-Post'', November 12, 1964</ref><ref name="Inky1">[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PI&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB5CDACEFF8CB9D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Jennifer Farrell, "A Different Track \ Model Train Club Aboard New Line", ''Philadelphia Inquirer'', January 11, 1999]</ref><ref name="Courpo3">[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Avis=BZ&Dato=20101205&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=12050801&Ref=PH Scott Anderson, "Model Railroad Open House", ''Camden NJ Courier-Post'', December 6, 2010]</ref> by members of the former [[Philadelphia Model Railroad Club]], which had been located in the [[24th Street Station (Philadelphia)|B&O passenger station]] on Chestnut St. in [[Philadelphia]],<ref name="Obsrv1" /><ref name="retro1">[http://theretrospect.com/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=1&twindow=&mad=&sdetail=1629&wpage=1&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=1155&hn=theretrospect&he=.com Sam Steinruck, "Model Train Layout A Little Bit of Christmas", ''The Retrospective'', December 5, 2008]</ref> after the B&O station was demolished. (Some members of the PMRC also went on to start the [[East Penn Traction Club]] several years later.)<ref name="eptc1">[http://www.eastpenn.org/origin.html The East Penn Traction Club: The Origin of Modular Trolley Layout]</ref> When first started, the space was an 80' x 35' unfinished crawl space directly under the original 1890's chapel. Finishing the space took weeks, with the removal of 4' of dirt<ref name="Inky1" /> before 20 cubic yards of concrete was used for the new floor.<ref name="hadgaz">"Cherry Valley RR: Ready to Roll", ''The Haddon Gazette'', November 8, 1962</ref> The first [[Model railroad layout|layout]] in the space was started in July 1962,<ref name="hadgaz4">"Modern Gullivers", ''The Haddon Gazette'', November 7, 1963</ref> with the framing and scenery built before the track was laid, and the first spike driven on August 30, 1962.<ref name="hadgaz" /> This layout was 27 by 55 feet in size,<ref name="Courpo4">"15 Model Railroaders Plan Exhibit at Church Festival", ''Camden NJ Courier-Post'', November 10, 1967</ref> and was of a [[Model railroad layout#Track layout|double-track folded dogbone design]], built with traditional square tabletop framing, [[Rail transport modelling#Landscaping|plaster scenery]], and [[Control relay|relay control]].<ref name="Obsrv1" /> Eventually it grew to have over 4000 linear feet of track,<ref name="Inky1" /> in both [[Standard gauge|standard]] and [[Narrow gauge railroads in the United States|3-foot]] gauges, with some [[dual gauge]] mixed in.<ref name="Courpo4" /> It existed through to January 1999,<ref name="Inky1" /> when it was torn down due to growing problems with accessibility and electrical characteristics.<ref name="Obsrv1" /><ref name="Inky1" /> Many of the original [[Building model|structures]] and [[Railroad switch|switches]] have been saved, for eventual inclusion on the new layout. Most notable of these is a 1940s train station model which had previously been salvaged from the layout at the PMRC location on Chestnut Street.<ref name="Obsrv1" /><ref name="hadgaz2">"Model Railroad Invites Inspection", ''The Haddon Gazette'', November 2, 1967</ref>
2012 was officially recognized as the club's 50th anniversary, by proclamation of the [[Merchantville, New Jersey|Merchantville]] Town Council, at their October public session.<ref name="Obsrv1" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20161227095605/http://merchantvillenj.gov/attachments/category/61/10.15.12.pdf Merchantville Town Council Agenda for October 15, 2012]</ref>
==New layout== The new [[Model railroad layout|layout]] was started in 2001,<ref name="retro2">Bethany Mitros, "World's A Stage: Cherry Valley Trains Are Actors", ''The Retrospective'', January 4, 2013</ref> is of a [[Model railroad layout#Track layout|double-track looped-8 design]]; but has been built around the walls, with several [[Balloon loop|reversing loops]], curved laminate benchwork, more than 2000 linear feet of track,<ref name="Courpo5">[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2012301080027 Joe Cooney, "Train Club's Open House Features All the Bells and Whistles", ''Camden NJ Courier-Post'', January 8, 2012]</ref> and a scale model of [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia's]] [[30th Street Station (Philadelphia)|30th Street Station]].<ref name="retro2" /> Scenery has been built with a mix of [[hydrocal]] and [[Extruded polystyrene|extruded styrofoam]] board, and [[NCE Corporation|North Coast Engineering (NCE)]] [[Digital Command Control]] has been installed to allow running of multiple trains without the need for complex [[Control relay|relay systems]].<ref name="retro1" /><ref name="Courpo5" /> The layout also features working signals that display proper occupancy, as well as scale-sized lighting fixtures for night scenes. Additionally, a new On30 narrow gauge branchline is being constructed at one end of the layout, with plans to expand it as time and resources allow.<ref name="retro1" /> [[Rolling stock]] is owned by the individual members,<ref name="retro1" /><ref name="hadgaz2" /> with the club jointly owning the [[Model railroad layout|layout]] and [[Rail transport modelling#Control|control system]]. This rolling stock represents all periods of history,<ref name="retro2" /> and is a mixture of [[Brass model|brass]], bronze, tin, [[white metal]], [[Plastic model|plastic]], [[Resin casting|resin]], wood, [[Paper model|paper]], cardboard, and [[Diecast toy|die-cast]] models; most of which has been extensively [[kitbashing|kitbashed]]/modified, features custom paint and [[Water slide decal|water-slide decals]]; and has been [[Rail transport modelling#Weathering|weathered]] to better replicate real-world conditions.<ref name="retro1" />
==Catenary== [[Image:Cvmrr-catenary.jpg|thumb|right|PRR-style compound catenary being installed on new layout.]]
Although the original layout did have a short section of [[Overhead lines#Overhead catenary|catenary]], most of it was destroyed when the layout was torn down.<ref name="Inky1" /> However, the new layout is being constructed with a full [[Pennsylvania Railroad#Electrification|PRR-Style compound catenary system]] over the entire layout. This catenary system is being integrated into the power distribution,<ref name="retro2" /> so that the [[electric locomotive]]s and [[Electric Multiple Unit|MU cars]] will receive power via their [[Pantograph (rail)|operating pantographs]].<ref name="Courpo6">"Hobbyists On The Right Track", ''Camden NJ Courier-Post'', January 7, 2013</ref>
==Board of directors== The club is governed by president, vice president, treasurer, and secretary. All officers serve, on a voluntary basis, as the organization's Board of Directors.
==Meetings== Meetings are held each Thursday evening. Business meetings are typically held on the second Thursday of the month.
==Open House events== Every year, the club traditionally has several "Open House" weekends near the end of the year, in conjunction with the [[Merchantville, New Jersey|Merchantville]] annual Christmas parade and Tree Lighting ceremony.<ref name="Obsrv1" /><ref name="bee1">"Calling All Model Train Enthusiasts", ''Beverly Bee'', December 2009</ref> The first such Open House weekends were held Friday and Saturday, November 9–10 and 16-17, 1962. Admission is free (donations requested).<ref name="aap1" /><ref name="Courpo1" /><ref name="Courpo6"/>
==O-scale Swap Meet events== The Club hosts two O-scale-only "[[Flea market|Swap Meets]]" a year, usually on a single first Saturday in both March and September.<ref name="hadgaz3">"Here She Comes", ''The Haddon Gazette'', November 3, 1966</ref> Admission to the Dealer's Hall is set at $5, and includes a tour of the layout. No meet has been scheduled for 2017.
==Membership== Club membership is open to everyone over the age of 18. Annual dues is $150.00 and new members have a six-month probation period.
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cherry Valley O-Scale}} [[Category:Rail transport modelling associations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in New Jersey]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1962]] [[Category:Merchantville, New Jersey]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Circassians in Iraq |image = [[File:North Caucasus and Iraq.png|250px]] |caption = The [[North Caucasus]] (in green) and [[Iraq]] (in red). |population = 30,000 - 50,000 |popplace = [[Baghdad]], [[Sulaymaniyah Province|Sulaymaniyah]]
[[Diyala Province|Diyala]], [[Kirkuk Province|Kirkuk]], [[Anbar Province|Anbar]], [[Najaf]] |langs = Mainly [[Mesopotamian Arabic|Arabic]] or [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]] as well as either:
[[Adyghe language|Adyghe]], [[Chechen language|Chechen]], [[Lezgian language|Lezgin]], [[Azerbaijani language|Turkmen]] |rels = [[Sunni Islam]] |related = [[North Caucasian peoples]] }} '''Circassians in Iraq''' are people of [[North Caucasus|North Caucasian]] origin in [[Iraq]], including [[Adyghe people|Adyghes]], [[Chechen people|Chechens]] and [[Dagestan]]is. The name "[[Circassians|Circassian]]" usually denotes speakers of {{nowrap|[[Northwest Caucasian languages]]}} only, however in {{nowrap|[[Western Asia]]}} the name may denote {{nowrap|North Caucasus peoples}} in general,{{cite journal|author1=Ahmet Katav |author2=Bilgay Duman |title=Iraqi Circassians (Chechens, Dagestanis, Adyghes) |journal=ORSAM Reports |date=November 2012 |issue=134 |url=http://www.orsam.org.tr/en/enUploads/Article/Files/20121116_134ingtum.pdf |accessdate=15 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403142200/http://www.orsam.org.tr/en/enUploads/Article/Files/20121116_134ingtum.pdf |archivedate=3 April 2013 |df= }} including [[Chechen people|Chechens]] and [[Dagestan]]is, who speak {{nowrap|[[Northeast Caucasian languages]]}}. ==History== Iraqis of North Caucasus origin mainly originate from [[Circassia]], [[Chechnya]] and [[Dagestan]]. {{nowrap|North Caucasian}} tribes which settled in Iraq include: [[Abkhaz people|Abkhaz]], [[Adyghe people|Adyghes]], [[Kabarday|Kabardin]], [[Shapsugs]], [[Ingush people|Ingush]], [[Chechen people|Chechens]], [[Avar people (Caucasus)|Avars]], [[Lezgian people|Lezgins]], and [[Kumyks]]. The migration of North Caucasians to Iraq goes back many centuries, peaking during the {{nowrap|[[Caucasian War]]}} {{nowrap|(1817–1864)}} and in the aftermath of the {{nowrap|[[Russian–Circassian War]]}} with the {{nowrap|[[Ethnic cleansing of Circassians|Circassian Exile]]}} of the 1860s. [[Adyghe people|Adyghes]] came to Iraq in two waves: directly from [[Circassia]], and later from the [[Balkans]]. [[Chechen people|Chechens]] and [[Dagestan]]is also settled in Iraq throughout the {{nowrap|[[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman era]]}}. Circassians also settled in large numbers in other neighbouring countries including [[Turkey]], [[Syria]], [[Jordan]], and [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]]. Like all Iraqis, Circassians in Iraq faced various hardships in the modern era, as Iraq suffered wars, sanctions, {{nowrap|oppressive regimes}}, and civil strife. ==Demographics== [[File:Flag of Adygea.svg|thumb|right|135px|Flag of [[Adygea]]]] [[File:National Flag of Chechen Republic of Ichkeria without Coat of Arms.png|thumb|right|135px|Flag of [[Chechnya]]]] [[File:Flag of Dagestan.svg|thumb|right|135px|Flag of [[Dagestan]]]] [[File:Flag of Ingushetia.svg|thumb|right|135px|Flag of [[Ingushetia]]]] The overall number of Circassians or people of North Caucasus origin in Iraq is estimated to be between 30,000 and 50,000,{{cite web|title=Adyghe People|url=http://www.joshuaproject.net/peoples.php?peo3=10161|publisher=[[Joshua Project]]|accessdate=15 April 2013}}{{cite web|title=Estimated population of Circassians|url=http://www.circassiannation.org/circassiannation_019.htm|publisher=CircassianNation.org|accessdate=15 April 2013}} however the total number is unknown. It has been reported that there are 30,000 [[Adyghe people|Adyghe]] families in [[Baghdad]] alone. It is understood that many {{nowrap|North Caucasians}} have ethnically assimilated into the Iraqi population, becoming Arabicized or Kurdicized. [[Chechen people|Chechens]] may comprise up to {{nowrap|three-quarters}} of Iraqis of {{nowrap|North Caucasian}} origin. Surnames such as ''Al-Daghestani'', ''[[Shishani (surname)|Al-Shishani]]'' ("Chechen"), and ''Al-Sharkas'' ("Circassian") are common among Iraqis of {{nowrap|North Caucasian}} descent. ===Population=== North Caucasians have settled in all parts of Iraq, from [[Dohuk]] in the north to [[Basra]]h in the south. The largest communities are in [[Baghdad]], [[Sulaymaniyah Governorate|Sulaymaniyah]], [[Diyala Governorate|Diyala]], [[Kirkuk Governorate|Kirkuk]], and [[Fallujah]], with smaller communities in [[Najaf]], [[Hillah]], [[Mosul]], [[Kut]], [[Basra]]h, [[Tikrit]], [[Erbil]], [[Nasiriyah]], [[Al Diwaniyah|Diwaniyah]], [[Dohuk]], [[Ramadi]], [[Amarah]], and {{nowrap|[[Tuz Khormato]]}}. There are also several Circassian villages throughout Iraq, including a Chechen neighbourhood in [[Baghdad]]. ===Culture=== North Caucasians in Iraq have integrated into Iraqi society while preserving their traditional {{nowrap|North Caucasian}} culture and customs, such as the Khabze culture. They continue to preserve certain {{nowrap|North Caucasian}} traditions in wedding ceremonies, birth ceremonies, and other special occasions, and to cook their traditional cuisine. In 2004, the {{nowrap|[[Al-Tadamun Society of Iraqi, Chechen, Dagestani and Circassian Tribes]]}} was formed in [[Kirkuk]]. This cultural organization seeks to bring together Iraqis of {{nowrap|North Caucasian}} heritage. {{nowrap|"Al-Tadamun"}} can be translated as "Solidarity". North Caucasians in Iraq are predominantly {{nowrap|[[Sunni Islam|Sunni Muslims]]}} like their ethnic counterparts in other countries. It is possible that a minority may also identify with {{nowrap|[[Shia Islam]]}}, the majority faith in Iraq. ===Language=== North Caucasians in Iraq speak a number of languages, including their native languages of either [[Adyghe language|Adyghe]], [[Chechen language|Chechen]], or [[Lezgian language|Lezgin]], as well as {{nowrap|[[Mesopotamian Arabic]]}}, [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], or [[Azerbaijani language|Turkmen]]. The native languages are mainly spoken by the elder generations, with younger people usually speaking only Arabic or Kurdish, the main Iraqi languages. ==South Caucasians== Many peoples of [[South Caucasus]] origin have also settled in Iraq, including [[Armenians in Iraq|Armenians]] and [[Iraqi Turkmens|Azerbaijanis]]. Ethnic [[Georgian people|Georgians]] also settled in Iraq historically, and actually {{nowrap|[[Mamluk dynasty of Iraq|ruled the country]]}} through the 18th and early 19th centuries {{nowrap|(from 1704 to 1831)}}. The Georgians who settled in Iraq were Muslim and ultimately assimilated into the Iraqi population, as a {{nowrap|Georgian-speaking}} community no longer exists in the country. {{nowrap|[[Naji Shawkat]]}}, the {{nowrap|[[Prime Minister of Iraq]]}} from 1932 to 1933 was of Georgian descent. ==Notable people== *[[Mahmud Shevket Pasha|Mahmud Shawkat Pasha]] – Ottoman general and statesman. *[[Hikmat Sulayman]] – Prime Minister of Iraq (1936–1937). *[[Tahir Yahya]] – Prime Minister of Iraq (1963–1965 and 1967–1968). ==See also== *[[Circassians in Syria]] *[[Circassians in Turkey]] *[[Circassians in Iran]] *[[Circassian diaspora]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Circassian diaspora}} {{Demographics of Iraq}} {{Iraq topics}} [[Category:Abkhaz diaspora]] [[Category:Avar diaspora]] [[Category:Chechen diaspora]] [[Category:Circassian diaspora in Asia|Iraq]] [[Category:Dagestani diaspora]] [[Category:Demographics of Iraq]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Iraq]] [[Category:Ingush diaspora]] [[Category:Iraqi people of Chechen descent| ]] [[Category:Iraqi people of Circassian descent| ]] [[Category:Iraqi people of Dagestani descent| ]] [[Category:Kumyk diaspora]] [[Category:Lezgian diaspora]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2008}}
'''Communication noise''' refers to influences on effective [[communication]] that influence the interpretation of [[conversation]]s. While often looked over, communication noise can have a profound impact both on our perception of [[social interaction|interactions]] with others and our analysis of our own communication proficiency.
Forms of communication noise include [[psychology|psychological]] noise, physical noise, [[physiology|physiological]] and [[semantic]] noise. All these forms of noise subtly, yet greatly influence our communication with others and are vitally important to anyone’s skills as a competent communicator.
==Psychological noise== Psychological noise results from preconceived notions we bring to conversations, such as racial [[stereotype]]s, reputations, [[bias]]es, and assumptions. When we come into a conversation with ideas about what the other person is going to say and why, we can easily become blinded to their original message. Most of the time psychological noise is impossible to free ourselves from, and we must simply strive to recognize that it exists and take those distractions into account when we converse with others.
==Environmental Noise== Environmental noise is the summary of [[noise pollution]] from outside, caused by transport, industrial and recreational activities.
==Physical noise== Physical noise is any external or environmental [[Stimulus (physiology)|stimulus]] that distracts us from receiving the intended message sent by a communicator (Rothwell 11). Examples of physical noise include: others talking in the background, background music, a startling noise and acknowledging someone outside of the conversation.
==Semantic noise== This is noise caused by the sender. i.e., the encoder. This type of noise occurs when grammar or technical language is used that the receiver (the decoder) cannot understand, or cannot understand it clearly. It occurs when the sender of the message uses a word or a phrase that we don't know the meaning of, or which we use in a different way from the speakers. This is usually due to the result that the encoder had failed to practice audience analysis at first. The type of audience is the one that determine the jargon one will use.
==References== * Rothwell,Dan J. ''In the Company of Others: An Introduction to Communication''. New York: McGraw Hill, 2004
[[Category:Communication]]

{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Copts in Sudan |image = |popplace = 500,000Minority Rights Group International, World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples – Sudan : Copts, 2008, available at: http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/49749ca6c.html [accessed 21 December 2010] |langs = [[Arabic language|Arabic]]
Liturgical: [[Coptic language]] |rels = [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodoxy]] }} [[File:Coptic cathedral (Khartoum) 001.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Holy Mary Coptic Orthodox Cathedral, [[Khartoum]], [[Sudan]].]] '''Copts in Sudan''' may refer to people born in or residing in [[Sudan]] of full or partial [[Coptic people|Coptic]] origin. Sudan has a native Coptic minority, although many Copts in Sudan are descended from more recent Coptic immigrants from Egypt. Copts in Sudan live mostly in northern cities, including [[Al Obeid]], [[Atbara]], [[Dongola]], [[Khartoum]], [[Omdurman]], [[Port Sudan]], and [[Wad Medani]]. They number up to 500,000, or slightly over 1% of the Sudanese population. Due to their advanced education, their role in the life of the country has been more significant than their numbers suggest. They have occasionally faced forced conversion to [[Islam]], resulting in their emigration and decrease in number. Modern immigration of Copts to Sudan peaked in the early 19th century, and they generally received a tolerant welcome there. However, this was interrupted by a decade of persecution under [[History of Mahdist Sudan|Mahdist rule]] at the end of the 19th century. As a result of this persecution, many were forced to relinquish their faith, adopt [[Islam]], and intermarry with the native Sudanese. The [[Anglo-Egyptian Sudan|Anglo-Egyptian invasion]] in 1898 allowed Copts greater religious and economic freedom, and they extended their original roles as artisans and merchants into trading, banking, engineering, medicine, and the civil service. Proficiency in business and administration made them a privileged minority. However, the return of [[Islamism|militant Islam]] in the mid-1960s and subsequent demands by radicals for an [[Sharia|Islamic constitution]] prompted Copts to join in public opposition to religious rule. [[Gaafar Nimeiry]]'s introduction of Islamic [[Sharia]] law in 1983 began a new phase of oppressive treatment of Copts, among other non-Muslims. After the overthrow of Nimeiry, Coptic leaders supported a secular candidate in the 1986 elections. However, when the [[National Islamic Front]] overthrew the elected government of [[Sadiq al-Mahdi]] with the help of the military, discrimination against Copts returned in earnest. Hundreds of Copts were dismissed from the civil service and judiciary. In February 1991, a Coptic pilot working for [[Sudan Airways]] was executed for illegal possession of foreign currency.[http://www.sudanupdate.org/REPORTS/PEOPLES/COPTS.HTM The Copts] Before his execution, he had been offered amnesty and money if he converted to [[Islam]], but he refused. Thousands attended his funeral, and the execution was taken as a warning by many Copts, who began to flee the country. Restrictions on the Copts' rights to Sudanese nationality followed, and it became difficult for them to obtain Sudanese nationality by birth or by naturalization, resulting in problems when attempting to travel abroad. The confiscation of Christian schools and the imposition of an Arab-Islamic emphasis in language and history teaching were accompanied by harassment of Christian children and the introduction of [[hijab]] dress laws. A Coptic child was flogged for failing to recite a [[Koranic]] verse. In contrast with the extensive media broadcasting of the Muslim [[Friday prayers]], the radio ceased coverage of the Christian Sunday service. As the civil war raged throughout the 1990s, the government focused its religious fervour on the south. Although experiencing discrimination, the Copts and other long-established Christian groups in the north had fewer restrictions than other types of Christians in the [[South Sudan|south]]. Today, the [[Coptic Church]] in Sudan is officially registered with the government, and is exempt from property tax. In 2005, the Sudanese government of National Unity (GNU) named a [[Coptic Orthodox]] priest to a government position, though the ruling Islamist party's continued dominance under the GNU provides ample reason to doubt its commitment to broader religious or ethnic representation. ==Notable Copts in Sudan== *[[Bishop Karas]], a Coptic Orthodox bishop born in Sudan. *[[Ra'ouf Mus'ad]], a playwright, journalist and novelist born in Sudan. ==See also== *[[Coptic diaspora]] *[[Christianity in Sudan]] *[[Copts in Egypt]] *[[Copts in Libya]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Coptic diaspora}} {{Demographics of Sudan}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Sudan]] [[Category:Sudanese people of Coptic descent| ]] [[Category:Coptic people]] [[Category:Coptic diaspora by country|Sudan]] [[Category:Oriental Orthodoxy in Sudan]] [[Category:Eastern Christianity in Sudan]]
