He was recalled to Bulozi | family5 = ? | image5 = | alt5 = | name6 = '''6.''' Nobleman '''[[Induna Imasiku]]''' | nickname6 = | native6 = | life6 = At Lukwakwa in Manyinga | reignstart6 = ? | reignend6 = ? | notes6 = Induna Imasiku was sent to preside over Chief Chikufele Muviwa local court on a caretaker basis. The time Induna Imasiku was presiding over Chief Chikufele's local court, he appointed Kalunga Samusandi to be a junior Induna in Chief Chikufele's local court. Shortly thereafter, Induna Imasiku appointed and enthroned Kalunga Samusandi as the first Chief of the Luchazi tribe in the Manyinga area. | family6 = ? | image6 = | alt6 = | name7 = '''7.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Chikufele Muviwa]]''' | nickname7 = | native7 = | life7 = His Palace was at Lukwakwa in Manyinga | reignstart7 = 1935 | reignend7 = ? | notes7 = In 1932, Chief Mwene Chikufele Muviwa returned to Katuba, in Manyinga area but as an ordinary person, without royal powers. In 1935, the Lozi King at Lealuyi, in agreement with Mbundas at Lukwakwa, reinstalled Chief Chikufele Muviwa on his Throne. Later, groups of Luchazi started moving further East from Chief Shinde's area, where they settled earlier and were welcomed and given land in the Upper Mumbeji, by Chief Chikufele, under the Manyinga Native Authorities. This was followed by groups of Chokwes, Luvales and Lundas (not in any sequence). In 1941, before Kabompo Boma came into existence, the Government separated Zambezi from Barotseland. Chief Chikufele had two other Mbunda subordinated chiefs namely Chiengele, Vulamitata and two others: a Nkoya called Mutinginyi and a Luchazi called Kalunga. In 1944 recognition was withdrawn from Mutinginyi and Vulamitata. In 1945 Induna Imasiku was recalled to Barotseland. The Mbunda in Manyinga resolved never again to be presided by a Barotseland Indunas. Chief Shinde of Zambezi wanted to control Manyinga in order to include it to his Zambezi areas. However, Manyinga people and village headmen rejected th Chief Shinde's move, contending that; the Chikufele chieftainship is the earlier and most senior in Manyinga, and that the first local court in Manyinga was his at his palace. An election was therefore organized, comprising more than 300 village headmen and all chiefs in the area, and Chief Chikufele was elected the Senior Chief of Manyinga Native Authority. Manyinga Native Aothority was at his palace. Senior Chief Chikufele then decreed that; he had broken away from Barotseland and that he would remain independent at Manyinga with the Mbunda chieftainship and that, it should be known that he was a Mbunda. Chief Mwene Chikufele remained a supreme power in the political administration of the whole Manyinga area and was seen as a symbol of the British administrative system. He was to be helped by the Council whose powers he could not to overrule. There were administrative villages called Ndandanda (or ndandanga) which consisted of membo (villages) | family7 = ? | image7 = | alt7 = | name8 = '''8.''' However his reign was short lived. | family8 = | image8 = | alt8 = | name9 = '''9.''' == Chief Mwene Kathimba Dynasty == This is a Mbunda Chieftainship related to Chief Chitengi Chingumbe Chiyengele, which was later recognised after the Kaonde/Lozi war, which the Lozis won with the help of the Mbunda war machinery, resulting in the Mbunda Chieftainship of Chief Mwene Kathimba having firmly been established at the confluence of the Lalafuta and Kyamenge in 1893, opposite Chief Mushima Njivumina of the Kaonde. The chieftainship of the Chief Mwene Kathimba brought peace to the area. It is said that when the first Mwene Kathimba arrived, Nkoya inhabiitants of the area were forced to live in stockaded villages for fear of the Kaonde who were their enemies at that time. But today all three peoples co-exist with mutual respect in Kaoma District of the Western Province of Zambia.

Mwene Kathimba Kafunya left Nakalomo in Bulozi to hunt for game in the Kaonde areas of Chiefs Kasempa, Kasonso and Chief Mushima. Later, the Lozi Paramout Chief recognized him as chief and he was installed as chief at the confluence of the Lalafuta and Kyamenge in 1893, opposite Chief Mushima Njivumina of the Kaonde. == Chief Mwene Chiyengele Chingumbe Dynasty == This is a Mbunda Chieftainship from [[List of the rulers of the Mbunda Kingdom|King Mwene Chingumbe Chingumbe Cha Choola]] and related to [[List of the rulers of the Mbunda Kingdom|Chief Chiyengele Chitenge Chingumbe]] the 15th Mbunda monarch, who migrated to Kayombo in the now Kabompo District. The succession list though is not complete, more data will be added in future.

== Chief Mwene Kandombwe Dynasty == The Mwene Kandombwe chieftainship originates from the central Mbunda royal line (Mbunda-Mathzi). The first Mwene Kandombwe was the son of Chieftainess Vamwene Machalo, one of the three sisters of [[List of the rulers of the Mbunda Kingdom|King Mwene Yambayamba]] and [[List of the rulers of the Mbunda Kingdom|King Mwene Chingumbe]] with the Luvale prince-consort named Chivinda cha Nkoshi, in [[Angola]].
{{Succession table monarch | name1 = '''1.''' Chief '''[[Mbunda people|Mwene Kandombwe Mumbwala]]''' | nickname1 = | native1 = | life1 = His Palace was at an area between Luvuji and Kahuli rivers in nakalomo, now Lukulu of Bulozi | reignstart1 = 1915 | reignend1 = ? | notes1 = Before migrating to Bulozi now [[Zambia]], Chief Mwene Kandombwe Mumbwala he used to visit the Aluyi King Ngombala. He migrated to Bulozi during the reign of Aluyi King Yeta, and was given land to settle with his people by the Aluyi King's Nobleman, Induna Imusunga Malamo. | family1 = ? | image1 = | alt1 = | name2 = '''2.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kandombwe Mbundu Kayawe]]''' | nickname2 = | native2 = | life2 = His Palace was at an area between Luvuji and Kahuli rivers in Lukulu of Bulozi | reignstart2 = ? | reignend2 = ? | notes2 = | family2 = ? | image2 = | alt2 = | name3 = '''3.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kandombwe Chifwelu Kakoma]]''' | nickname3 = | native3 = | life3 = His Palace was at an area between Luvuji and Kahuli rivers in Lukulu of Bulozi | reignstart3 = ? | reignend3 = ? | notes3 = | family3 = ? | image3 = | alt3 = | name4 = '''4.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kandombwe Kahuma Mulejima]]''' | nickname4 = | native4 = | life4 = His Palace was at an area between Luvuji and Kahuli rivers in Lukulu of Bulozi | reignstart4 = ? | reignend4 = ? | notes4 = | family4 = ? | image4 = | alt4 = | name5 = '''5.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kandombwe Ka Machalo]]''' | nickname5 = | native5 = | life5 = His Palace is at an area between Luvuji and Kahuli rivers in Lukulu District, Western Province of Zambia | reignstart5 = ? | reignend5 = The current by 2014 on the throne | notes5 = His local court on which he sits is at Luvuji in Lukulu District, Western Province of Zambia. | family5 = ? | image5 = [[File:Mwene Kandombwe Ka Machalo is one of the Mbunda Chief in Zambia.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mwene Kandombwe Ka Machalo, one of Mbunda Chiefs in Zambia|Mwene Kandombwe Ka Machalo]], the 5th in the Chief Mwene Kandombwe Dynasty of the [[Mbunda people]] in Zambia]] | alt5 =
}}
== Chief Mwene Kasavi Dynasty == The Mwene Kasavi chieftainship originates from the central Mbunda royal line (Mbunda-Mathzi). The first Chief Mwene Kasavi was the son of [[List of the rulers of the Mbunda Kingdom|King Mwene Nyumbu Luputa]] (one of the nephews of [[List of the rulers of the Mbunda Kingdom|King Mwene Yambayamba]] and [[List of the rulers of the Mbunda Kingdom|King Mwene Chingumbe]]) whose mother Queen Valishano Chikanda was from the Mbunda - Mbalango branch of the Mbunda chieftainship.
{{Succession table monarch | name1 = '''1.''' Chief '''[[Mbunda people|Mwene Kasavi ka Chikanda]]''' | nickname1 = | native1 = | life1 = His Palace was at Lukute, then Mankoya of Bulozi | reignstart1 = 1918 | reignend1 = ? | notes1 = Mwene Kasavi ka Chikanda had his palace at Mbakala in Mushuma, [[Angola]]. Later he migrated to Bulozi with his people in 1918. | family1 = ? | image1 = | alt1 = | name2 = '''2.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kasavi Kayawe]]''' | nickname2 = | native2 = | life2 = His Palace was at Lukute, then Mankoya of Bulozi | reignstart2 = ? | reignend2 = ? | notes2 = | family2 = ? | image2 = | alt2 = | name3 = '''3.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kasavi Kakoma]]''' | nickname3 = | native3 = | life3 = His Palace was at Lukute, then Mankoya of Bulozi | reignstart3 = ? | reignend3 = ? | notes3 = | family3 = ? | image3 = | alt3 = | name4 = '''4.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kasavi Kambili]]''' | nickname4 = | native4 = | life4 = His Palace was at Lukute, then Mankoya, now Kaoma District of Western Province in [[Zambia]] | reignstart4 = ? | reignend4 = ? | notes4 = | family4 = ? | image4 = | alt4 = | name5 = '''5.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kasavi Kapitango]]''' | nickname5 = | native5 = | life5 = His Palace was at Lukute, then Mankoya, now Kaoma District of Western Province in [[Zambia]] | reignstart5 = ? | reignend5 = ? | notes5 = | family5 = ? | image5 = | alt5 = | name6 = '''6.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kasavi Makayi]]''' | nickname6 = | native6 = | life6 = His Palace was at Lukute, then Mankoya, now Kaoma District of Western Province in [[Zambia]] | reignstart6 = ? | reignend6 = ? | notes6 = | family6 = ? | image6 = | alt6 = | name7 = '''7.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kasavi Kamuwanga]]''' | nickname7 = | native7 = | life7 = His Palace was at Lukute, then Mankoya, now Kaoma District of Western Province in [[Zambia]] | reignstart7 = ? | reignend7 = ? | notes7 = | family7 = ? | image7 = | alt7 = | name8 = '''8.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Kasavi Kajila]]''' | nickname8 = | native8 = | life8 = His Palace is at Lukute, then Mankoya, now Kaoma District of Western Province in [[Zambia]] | reignstart8 = ? | reignend8 = The current by 2014 on the throne | notes8 = Controversy rages that the current Chief Mwene Kasavi Kajila hijacked the chieftainship. He does not hail from the Mbunda chieftainship but that, he is a [[Lovale|Luvale]] | family8 = ? | image8 = [[File:Mwene Kasavi Kajila is one of the Mbunda Chiefs in Zambia.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mwene Kasavi Kajila, one of Mbunda Chiefs in Zambia|Mwene Kasavi Kajila]], the 8th in the Chief Mwene Kasavi Dynasty of the [[Mbunda people]] in Zambia]] | alt8 =
}}
== Chief Mwene Lindeho Dynasty == The Mwene Lindeho chieftainship originates from Vamwene Singisingi or Thingithingi, a daughter of Vamwene Ngambo Lyambayi. The first Mwene Lindeho Kanyanyu came to Kalabo District from Nengu in the district of Lumbala Ngimbu in Angola.
{{Succession table monarch | name1 = '''1.''' Chief '''[[Mbunda people|Lindeho Kanyanyu]]''' | nickname1 = | native1 = | life1 = His Palace was at Chamemba in Kalabo of Bulozi | reignstart1 = ? | reignend1 = ? | notes1 = King Lubosi Lewanika received him well and gave him to rule the area of Chamemba, Keta, Kashiyana, Tunjamba, Sanja and Kate. A local court was established in his palace headquarters with the required royal privileges intact: mukupele drum, eland tail flyswitch, xylophones, court messengers, attendants and councillors. | family1 = ? | image1 = | alt1 = | name2 = '''2.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Lindeho Ngunga]]''' | nickname2 = | native2 = | life2 = His Palace was at Chamemba in Kalabo of Bulozi | reignstart2 = ? | reignend2 = ? | notes2 = He inherited the royal privileges and court of his predecessor. | family2 = ? | image2 = | alt2 = | name3 = '''3.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Lindeho Katolo Chiputa]]''' | nickname3 = | native3 = | life3 = His Palace was at Chamemba in Kalabo Kalabo District, Western Province of Zambia | reignstart3 = ? | reignend3 = 1991 | notes3 = During the time of Mwene Lindeho Katolo Chiputa the royal privileges and court were withdrawn by the Litunga in Lealui. This was done due to his difficult personality, lack of self dignity and unroyal ethics. He died in 1991 at Chamemba in Kalabo District in the Western Province of Zambia. | family3 = ? | image3 = | alt3 = | name4 = '''4.''' Chief '''[[Mwene Lindeho Ndilayi Kalipa]]''' | nickname4 = | native4 = | life4 = His Palace is at Chamemba in Kalabo Kalabo District, Western Province of Zambia | reignstart4 = ? | reignend4 = The current by 2014 on the throne | notes4 = | family4 = ? | image4 = [[File:Mwene Lindeho Kalipa is one of the Mbunda Chiefs in Zambia.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mwene Lindeho Ndilayi Kalipa, one of Mbunda Chiefs in Zambia|Lindeho Ndilayi Kalipa]], the 4th in the Chief Mwene Lindeho Dynasty of the [[Mbunda people]] in Zambia]] | alt4 =
}}

page.title: List of reportedly haunted locations in Thailand

revision.text:
'''[[Thailand]]''' is a country located in [[Southeast Asia]] with a [[History of Thailand|history of over 700 years]] and is mainly [[Buddhist]] [[Theravada Buddhism]]. However, many people still believe in and respect [[superstition]], the [[supernatural]], [[miracle]]s, [[Magic (paranormal)|magic]], [[animism]], [[amulet]]s, etc.
This is a list of locations in Thailand which are reported to be haunted or paranormal.
==Bangkok Metropolitan Region== [[File:Government House of Thailand.JPG|thumb|Government House of Thailand]] [[image:Sathorn Unique Tower by neajjean.jpg|thumb|Sathorn Unique Tower]] * '''[[Government House of Thailand]]''': The offices of the [[Prime Minister of Thailand]] and the appointed cabinet ministers. It is rumored to have many ghosts and [[paranormal]] activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clipmass.com/story/20760|title= เรื่องเล่าลี้ลับ ทำเนียบรัฐบาล|work=Clipmass|language=Thai}}</ref> * '''[[Phitsanulok Mansion]]''': The official residence of the [[Prime Minister of Thailand]]. Like the neighboring government house, the mansion is rumored to be haunted by many ghosts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.internationalcrimeauthors.com/?p=1746|title=A Thai Ghost Story by Christopher G. Moore|publisher=}}</ref> * '''Crime Suppression Division Jail Cell''': Many prisoners claim to have seen a male ghost wearing a red [[t-shirt]] in the jail cells, especially by prisoners on their first night. This ghost is said to persuade others to suicide by hanging.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thebangkokallegory.blogspot.com/2009/09/camera-man-captures-jail-cell-ghost.html|title=Camera Man Captures Jail Cell Ghost|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> * '''[[Lumphini Park]]''': A 360-[[Rai (area)|rai]] (57.6-hectares (142-acres)) park in [[Bangkok]], Thailand. It is said there is a haunted wood house in the park. At night people often heard a shrill cry from inside the park. During the protest of the [[People's Democratic Reform Committee]] (PDRC) while the protesters stayed in the park, some protesters experienced a haunting and a volunteer security guard was possessed at dawn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oknation.net/blog/nfedlion/2014/06/18/entry-3|title= อาถรรพ์...สวนลุมพินี เรื่องผีระหว่างการชุมนุม กปปส. โดย เถกิง สมทรัพย์ BlueSky|work=Oknation|language=thai}}</ref> * '''[[Ratchaprasong Intersection]]''': A road intersection in [[Pathum Wan District]], downtown Bangkok. It is both a popular tourist destination and a world-class shopping center. This place is rumored to be cursed or haunted, since the site of Prince [[Chudadhuj Dharadilok]]'s palace in the past. It is currently home to eight [[Hinduism|Hindu]] shrines, including [[Erawan Shrine]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ที่แรง! ถอดรหัส รวมเทพย่านราชประสงค์ |url= https://www.thairath.co.th/content/519168|date=2015-08-19|accessdate=2017-11-11|work=[[Thairath]]|language=thai}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=อาถรรพณ์วังเพชรบูรณ์ |url= https://www.thairath.co.th/content/446771|date=2017-08-31|accessdate=2017-11-11|work=Thairath|language=thai|author=บาราย}}</ref> * ''' Soi Watcharapol''': [[Soi (disambiguation)|Soi]] (side-road branching off a major road) in [[Bang Khen District]], Bangkok. A secluded location and well known to have several haunted houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://social.tnews.co.th/content/60716/|title= 10 อันดับ ซอย "สยองขวัญ" ในกรุงเทพและปริมณฑล|language=thai|work=Tnews}}</ref> * '''Wat Maha But''': [[Wat]] (Thai temple) in [[Suan Luang District]], Bangkok. Location established the [[Mae Nak Phra Khanong]] shrine and home to a famous [[Thai ghost]] legend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkok.com/shrines/mae-nak-shrine.htm#|title=Mae Nak Shrine in Bangkok|work=bangkok.com}}</ref> * '''Wat Samian Nari''': A temple in [[Chatuchak District]], Bangkok. There are many [[urban legends]] about women in black who appear here at night. They will call a taxi from [[Ratchadapisek Road]] to this temple, but then disappeare mysteriously. It is believed that these two women are sisters named "Chulee Thipsuksri" and "Sulee Thipsuksri" who died when their train was broken into two pieces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/culture/2016/10/31/cut-into-pieces-the-haunting-of-wat-samian-nari/|work=[[Khao Sod]]|title=CUT INTO PIECES: THE HAUNTING OF WAT SAMIAN NARI|date=2016-10-31|accessdate=2017-09-22|first=Chayanit|last= Itthipongmaetee}}</ref> The most recent sighting happened on the dawn of July 15, 2016 at about 4:00 am. Those who witnessed the incident told his story on [[Pantip.com]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnews.co.th/contents/197290|title=โคตรช็อก!! ชายหนุ่มเล่าเรื่องเจอผีผู้หญิงในตำนาน หน้าวัดเสมียนนารี ล่าสุดสดๆร้อนๆ (มีภาพ)|language=Thai|date=2016-07-23|accessdate=2017-09-30|work=Tnews}}</ref> * '''Cemetery of Wat Don''': A [[cemetery]] of Wat Don Kuson in [[Sathon District]]. In the past, it was a place that was rumored to be haunted.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Channel 3 (Thailand)|Channel 3]]|url=http://www.ch3thailand.com/news/scoop/10691|title=ป่าช้าวัดดอน สุสานสุดเฮี้ยน|language=thai|accessdate=2018-04-06}}</ref> * '''Talapat Suksa School''': The abandoned school building is located on Phraeng Nara Road, [[Phra Nakhon District]], its site in the popular tourist area and is the center of a number of famous restaurants in the old city area. It is named after [[née]] of Princess [[Srinagarindra]]. It was once the theater of Prince [[Narathip Praphanphong]]. People who live in this neighborhood see the ghost of an actress and also see the dream again.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://talk.mthai.com/journey/450112.html|title=Line กนก 3 แพร่ง|date=September 2017|author=thepureway|work=[[Nation TV (Thailand)|Nation TV]]|language=thai|accessdate=2018-03-21}}</ref> * '''Abbhantripaja's Palace''': The palace of Princese [[Abbhantripaja]], a daughter of [[King Rama V]], that was deserted after she dies. At night someone hears a woman cry or the sound of a swimmer, or sometimes lights turning on and off itself. At present it is both a [[café]], a [[library]] and a part of [[Chartthaipattana Party]] headquarters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnews.co.th/contents/352543|work=Tnews|date=2017-08-29|title=พระตำหนักอาถรรพ์!! วังเก่าของ "พระองค์เจ้าหญิงอัพภันตรีปชา" วันดีคืนดี...มีเสียงผู้หญิงร้องไห้ มีไฟสว่างโร่บนตำหนัก ทั้งๆที่ตัดไฟไปนานแล้ว!!|language=thai}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work=[[Pantip.com]]|url=http://topicstock.pantip.com/home/topicstock/2006/11/R4902130/R4902130.html|title=#### พาทัวร์ร้านกาแฟ คราวนี้เป็นตากล้องเองเลย ####|language=thai|author= mongkud|date=2006-11-23}}</ref> * '''[[Wat Suthat]]''': A temple built in the reign of [[King Rama I]], it is known as royal temple of the first grade and is a popular tourist attraction. There was a story about a tall [[hungry ghost]] called ''[[Preta]]''. However, this may have been the [[Giant Swing]] located in front of the temple, and the morning fog may have caused this sighting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.komchadluek.net/news/lifestyle/181800|title=เปรต:คำวัด|author=พระธรรมกิตติวงศ์|language=thai|date=2014-03-28|work=[[Komchadluek]]|accessdate=2018-03-21}}</ref> * '''[[Wat Suwannaram]]''': Old temple built in the [[Ayutthaya period]]. It is located in [[Bangkok Noi District]] on Bangkok's [[Thonburi]] side (west bank of [[Chao Phraya River]]). It was the capital during [[Thonburi Kingdom|the reign]] of [[King Taksin]]. During this time it was used to executions of prisoners of war, who were primarily Burmese soldiers. Recently, local people have seen Burmese ghosts haunting the temple. According to rumor, there are ''Preta'' on the [[Bell tower (wat)|bell tower]], a headless male ghost wearing [[chang kben]], and a female ghost on the pier in the middle of night.<ref>{{cite web|author=หนุ่มลูกทุ่ง|url=http://www.manager.co.th/Travel/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9500000128822|title=สยองขวัญวันปล่อยผี กับเรื่องผีๆในเมืองกรุง|date=2007-10-30|work=[[Manager Online]]|language=thai|accessdate=2018-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnews.co.th/contents/193786|title=ผวา!! หนุ่มเล่าเหตุการณ์หลังเจอดี "ผีหัวเรือ" วัดสุวรรณาราม งานนี้ถึงกับ..?(มีคลิป)|date=2016-06-28|accessdate=2018-03-21|work=Tnews|language=thai}}</ref> * '''[[Ratchadaphisek Road]]''': A major road in Chatuchak District, Bangkok. The curve of the road, opposite to the [[Criminal Court of Thailand|Criminal Court]], is a place with a large [[banyan]] tree and [[spirit house]], where car accidents often take place. It has been called the "Curve of Hundred Corpses".<ref>{{cite web|title=รื้อศาลโค้ง100ศพปิดตำนานเฮี้ยนถนนรัชดาฯ|url=http://www.komchadluek.net/news/crime/199718|date=2015-01-19|accessdate=2017-09-22|work=Komchadluek|language=thai|first=นิธิศ|last=นาเจริญ}}</ref> * '''[[Sathorn Unique Tower]]''': Unfinished [[skyscraper]] from [[1997 Asian financial crisis|1997 financial crisis]], located in downtown Bangkok by the Chao Phraya River. Notable for its ghost stories. Its story was adapted into the 2017 film ''[[The Promise (Thai film)|The Promise]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailynews.co.th/entertainment/591181|title= ดึงเรื่องตึกร้างกลางสาทร ทำหนังไทยสยองขวัญ!|work=Daily News|language=thai|accessdate=2017-08-19|date=2017-08-11}}</ref> * '''Thawi Watthana Deserted House''': A deserted house located in [[Thawi Watthana District]] in suburban Bangkok. In 2015 seven teenagers went [[ghost hunting]] here. After backing out, they gradually died from accidents such as motorcycle crash or a house fire until only two people were alive in 2017. This is similar to the case in the Hollywood film ''[[Final Destination (film)|Final Destination]]''. At each accident, there are witnesses claiming to see a mysterious woman with long hair wearing a white dress. A [[Mediumship|medium]] claimed that this is a [[vengeful spirit]] named "Dao" or "Deuan" that followed and killed these teenagers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pptvhd36.com/programs/%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%82%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A7/%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9B%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%99%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B7%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%87-%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9B%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%82%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A7/70106#part-1|work=[[PPTV (Thailand)|PPTV]]|title=เป็นเรื่อง! “อ.แบงค์” สื่อวิญญาณ รู้จัก “ผีบ้านร้าง” ชื่อ “ดาวเดือน” – นักวิชาการ สวน “งมงาย”|date=2017-08-31|accessdate=2017-09-02|language=thai}}</ref> * '''[[Mahidol University]]''': One of the leading [[List of universities and colleges in Thailand|universities in Thailand]] located in Tambon Salaya, [[Amphoe Phutthamonthon]], [[Nakhon Pathom province]]. This place was a [[funeral home]] during the reign of [[King Rama IV]] and King Rama V. There are now many respected shrines here. Many students have been thought to be possessed or haunted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oknation.nationtv.tv/blog/print.php?id=28089|work=Oknation|date=April 2007|accessdate=2017-09-24|language=thai|title=เรื่องเล่าในศาลายา..วิญญาณที่ยังวนเวียนอยู่เฝ้าดูพวกเรา|author=get away}}</ref> * '''Thai Lemon Foods Factory''': [[Lemon juice]] factory located in Tambon Nong Sam Wang, [[Amphoe Nong Suea]], [[Pathum Thani province]]. Factory's [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] captured a luminous floating head with gut female spirit called ''[[Krasue]]'' on the night of July 22, 2008 at about 11:30 pm. Locals insist that it looks like an old woman who lives alone in the neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tnews.teenee.com/weird/25728.html|title=ดวงไฟ-ลือกระสือ วงจรปิดจับภาพได้|date=2008-08-07|accessdate=2017-11-20|language=Thai|work=Tnews.teenee|author=พังจูดี้}}</ref>
==Central== [[File:Wat Kudi Dao, Ayutthaya 0311.jpg|thumb|Wat Kudi Dao, Ayutthaya]] * '''[[Ayutthaya Historical Park]]''': Historical areas have been the [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|ancient capital]] of [[Thai history]] for over 400 years from the 14th to the 18th century. There're many dynasties and monarchs. There're many rumors about cursed treasures and ghosts watching these treasures was called ''Pu Som Fao Sap''. Today there're many abandoned places that are the source of these rumors, such as [[Wat Phra Sri Sanphet]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailynews.co.th/foreign/191915|title= วัดในอยุธยาติดอันดับสถานที่น่ากลัวที่สุดในเอเชีย|language=Thai|work=[[Daily News (Thailand)|Daily News]]|date=2017-04-12|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref> Wat Kra Sai, Tri Muk Pavilion,<ref>{{IMDb title|3253618|I Wouldn't Go in There}}</ref> [[Wat Ratchaburana, Ayutthaya|Wat Ratchaburana]], [[Wat Kudi Dao]] etc. Especially at Wat Kudi Dao, Prince [[Birabongse Bhanudej]] saw ''Pu Som Fao Sap'' is the headless male ghost here in December 1960. He talked about this in later years and it made him change his ghostly attitude throughout life.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnews.co.th/contents/200970|title=เปิดอาถรรพ์!!! ขุมทรัพย์ "วัดกุฎีดาว" พระองค์เจ้าพีระพงษ์ภานุเดช เผชิญผีปู่โสมเฝ้าทรัพย์!(มีคลิป)|date=2016-08-21|accessdate=2017-08-19|language=Thai|work=Tnews}}</ref> * '''Sermon Hall of Wat Ban Kae''': Sermon hall of Wat Ban Kae in [[Amphoe Sawaeng Ha]], [[Ang Thong province]]. It was built in 1969 but has not been completed to date. Because all builders were haunted, and also the monks and the villagers were also haunted. Currently it is abandoned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sanook.com/1099994/|title=ผวาผีดุ! ลือศาลาการเปรียญวัดบ้านแกเฮี้ยน|work=Sanook|date=2015-02-22|accessdate=2017-11-21|language=Thai}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.ch7.com/detail/276681|title=ชาวบ้านผวา! ศาลาเฮี้ยนวัดบ้านแก จ.อ่างทอง จอมปลวกขึ้นรูปทรงคล้ายเศียรฤาษี|work=[[Channel 7 (Thailand)|Channel 7]]|date=2018-03-16|accessdate=2018-03-21|language=Thai}}</ref> * '''Wat Khao Kaeo''': Located in Tambon Ongkharak, [[Amphoe Pho Thong]], Ang Thong province. In early August 2012, a [[maechi]] had seen a ''Preta'' at this temple as she was praying. The villagers, including the police, have confirmed that they have been seen for many years and they were terrified.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hilight.kapook.com/view/74587|title=อึ้ง! เปรตโผล่วัดเขาแก้ว แม่ชีแผ่เมตตาให้ก็ไม่ไป|date=2012-08-04|accessdate=2017-11-26|work=Kapook|language=thai}}</ref> * '''Ang Thong Antique Bed''': Antique wooden bed more than 100 years old of Wat Thanon, Tambon Phong Pheng, [[Amphoe Pa Mok]], Ang Thong province, No one knows who owns it, but the locals who sleep or sit on this bed must face many inexplicable things until die.<ref>{{cite web|work=Thairath|date=2018-03-30|accessdate=2018-04-01|language=thai|title=อาถรรพ์เตียงโบราณ! ชาวโผงเผง ผวา ใครขึ้นนั่งเจอดีทุกรายถึงตายก็มี (คลิป) |url=https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1243449}}</ref> * '''Kanchanaburi Deep Jungle''': Deep jungle in [[Kanchanaburi province]], the border with [[Myanmar]]. The villagers who live here say that, in this jungle there's a legendary fruit that's a beautiful young women named ''[[Nariphon]]''. It has been searched by popular TV shows ''[[Destination Truth]]'' in 2011.<ref>{{IMDb title|1859752|"Destination Truth" Thai Tree People/Aiya Napa Monster}}</ref> * '''[[Kaeng Krachan National Park]]''': Is the [[List of national parks of Thailand|largest national park of Thailand]] located on the area of [[Phetchaburi province]]. It is on the border with Myanmar, contiguous with the [[Tanintharyi Nature Reserve]]. In the mid-2011, three [[Royal Thai Army]] helicopters crashed in only nine days, there were 17 deaths. [[Karen people|Karen]] believe this is a paranormal place alike [[Bermuda Triangle]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iam.hunsa.com/byline/article/86149|title=ไขปริศนาลี้ลับผืนป่า "แก่งกระจาน" อากาศ–อาถรรพ์–อาฆาต??|date=2011-07-29|accessdate=2017-12-02|language=thai|work=Hunsa|author= byline}}</ref>
==Eastern== * '''Mathayom Taksin Rayong School''': High school in [[Rayong]] City, [[Amphoe Mueang Rayong]], [[Rayong province]]. Many students and janitors claim this school is haunted. This place used to be a prison in the past.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hilight.kapook.com/view/112100 |title=โรงเรียนเฮี้ยน เจอผีตามหลอนแทบคลั่ง สั่งทำพิธีปลดปล่อยวิญญาณ|work=Kapook|language=thai}}</ref> * '''Mae Ram Phueng Beach''': The beach is a famous tourist attraction of Rayong province. However, there're always drowning victims until it called "Haunted Beach" or "Man-eater Beach". Those who visit or stay here often experience haunted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lifestyle.campus-star.com/scoop/4734.html|title=หาดแม่รำพึง ชื่อดังมาก ใน เรื่องผีดุ เชื่อว่า เป็น หาดผีสิง หรือ หาดกินคน !!|date=2015-12-22|accessdate=2017-11-21|language=thai|work=Lifestyle.compus-star|author=root}}</ref> * '''Abandoned Scout Camp''': Located in Rayong province founded in 1974. There was one scout drowned, and then there was the sight of his spirit. Today at the entrance there's a statue of a scout with a lot of sacrifice especially [[grenadine]]. The story of this place was told on radio program. It has been adapted into a horror film ''Black Full Moon'' in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.majorcineplex.com/news/ghost-story-from-camp|work=[[Major Cineplex]]|language=thai|date=2017-10-02|accessdate=2017-11-21|title=รวมเรื่องเล่าประสบการณ์เจอผีในค่ายลูกเสือ เฮี้ยนจริงจนต้องกลัว}}</ref> * '''Krasae Bon Cave''': Cave in the [[rain forest]] in [[Tambon]] Krasae Bon, [[Amphoe Klaeng]], Rayong province, it is about 500 meters from the nearest village. Locals often hear [[Music of Thailand|Thai music]] sound from within and seeing the strange lights floating from the cave.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thaich8.com/news_detail/59577/%E0%B8%9C%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B1%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%B9%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%9A%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%96%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%8C%E0%B8%96%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%B3-%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%B6%E0%B8%81%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B5%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%95%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B5%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B1%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%99|language=thai|date=2018-02-07|accessdate=2018-03-27|work=[[Channel 8 (Thailand)|Channel 8]]|title=ผวาทั้งหมู่บ้านอาถรรพ์ถ้ำ-กลางดึกเสียงดนตรีไทยดังลั่น}}</ref> * '''Ko Kham Noi''': A small island near [[Ko Sichang]], [[Chonburi province]] in the [[gulf of Thailand]] is about an hour's drive from [[Pattaya]] shore. It is a graveyard of many nationality people, many of the religions in the past, locals called "Ghost Island". It was called a very haunted island. Once upon a time, teenagers came to hunt for ghosts and heard mysterious sounds and saw a ghost of Muslim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bugaboo.tv/watch/218328|title=เปิดตำนานหลอน เกาะผีที่ชลบุรี แหล่งสุสานฝังศพ วัยรุ่นท้าทายเจอวิญญาณเฮี้ยน|date=2015-11-04|accessdate=2017-12-05|work=Channel 7|language=thai}}</ref>
==Northern== * '''[[Chiang Mai University]]''': The first public research university in [[northern Thailand]] founded in 1964. There're stories about ghosts, such as the seventh women dorm with the mysterious sound at night ''"Pok...Pok...Crued"''. Rumor says it is the sound of one student dragging herself over the stairs to get back to her room after being fatally assaulted or the pink room etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manager.co.th/Campus/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9520000126258|title=เรื่องลี้ลับ มช.ที่ไม่ได้มีแค่ ป็อก... ป็อก...ครืด|language=thai|work=Manager Daily|date=2009-10-24|accessdate=2017-11-20}}</ref> This mysterious sound has been created as one part of the [[Sahamongkol Film International]]'s horror film ''Haunted Universities'' in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nekonekomovielitterbox.wordpress.com/2010/04/22/haunted-universities-aka-%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%82%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%8D-2009-thai-ghost-horror/|title=“Haunted Universities” aka “มหา’ลัยสยองขวัญ” (2009) – Thai Ghost /Horror|date=2010-04-22|accessdate=2017-11-28|work=Nekonekmovielitterbox|author=Nekoneko}}</ref> * '''Mae Usu Cave''': The largest cave in [[Mae Moei National Park]], [[Tak province]]. [[S'gaw people]] believe that this place is home of ''Suea Saming'', a fierce half human, half tiger creature like [[Werecat]] or [[Skin-walker]]. And on the [[full moon]] night. There's a Thai music sound from inside.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manager.co.th/travel/viewnews.aspx?NewsID=9560000012415|first=ปิ่น|last=บุตรี|date=2013-01-30|accessdate=2017-11-20|work=Manager Online|language=thai|title= ถ้ำแม่อุสุ มหัศจรรย์โรงละครใต้พิภพ กับตำนานเสือสมิงสำนึกผิด/ปิ่น บุตรี}}</ref> * '''Ladda Land''': An abandoned botanical garden and amusement park including townhouse. The closure of the business since the early 1980s is one of the places in [[Chiang Mai province]] where the haunted. Its story was adapted into a [[GMM Tai Hub|GTH]]'s film ''[[Ladda Land]]'' in 2011. It is located near the [[700th Anniversary Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movie.sanook.com/16439/|title=ประวัติความสยองหมู่บ้าน ลัดดาแลนด์|date=2011-05-04|accessdate=2017-11-21|work=Sanook|language=thai}}</ref> * '''Din Piang Cave''': A cave on Phu Bo Bid in Tambon Kut Pong, [[Amphoe Mueang Loei]], [[Loei province]]. In late September 2016, a strange footprint was discovered with only three toes. The locals believe that be the footprints of ''[[Phi kong koi]]'', a hairy forest vampire with one leg and small shaped like a little boy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thairath.co.th/content/734304|date=2016-09-26|accessdate=2017-11-21|language=thai|work=Thairath|title=อึ้งรอยเท้าประหลาดเชื่อผีกองกอย}}</ref> * '''Field of Ban Thung Hee''': A field of Ban Thung Hee, Tambon Wang Sai Kham, [[Amphoe Wang Nuea]], [[Lampang province]]. On December 9, 2017, one villager found a strange human footprint, but it is bigger. It has a length of 30 cm and a distance of up to 170 cm each, so it is believed that it is not a footprint of the human course. The villagers believe that the footprint of [[tutelary deity|tutelary]], which they called ''Phra Chao Noke''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.ch7.com/detail/261054|title=ฮือฮา! พบรอยเท้าประหลาดกลางทุ่งนา ใหญ่กว่าคนปกติ 2 เท่า จ.ลำปาง|date=2017-12-11|accessdate=2017-12-11|work=Channel 7|language=Thai}}</ref>
==Northeastern (Isan region)== [[File:Wat Kham Chanot bridge-entrance.JPG|thumb|entrance to Kamchanod Forest]] * '''Kamchanod Forest''': is on a small island cut off by small waterways near the village of [[Tambon]] Wang Tong, [[Amphoe Ban Dung]], [[Udon Thani province]], and its dense forest is reputed by most locals to be the underground kingdom of the mythical [[Phaya Naga]] and one place of its most famous ghost stories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thaisabai.org/2009/06/the-ghosts-of-kamchanod/|title=The Ghosts of Kamchanod|work=Beyond the Mango Juice}}</ref> * '''Submafai Forest''': A forest area in [[Thap Lan National Park]], in mid-September 2017 one 73-year-old local woman went to collect mushrooms in the forest. She said that she was taken by a woman in green [[traditional Thai clothing]] to a house in the forest. She was well-groomed while her relatives searched for two days. Eventually, they found out that she had lost into the forest for two days, but her body condition is still remarkably clean despite the rain throughout.<ref>{{cite web|title=ยายโคราชหลงป่า 2วันเนื้อตัวสะอาด เผยหญิงชุดไทยพาไปบ้าน ให้เลขเสี่ยงโชค|url=https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1067787|date=2017-09-12|accessdate=2017-09-15|work=Thairath|language=Thai}}</ref> * '''Tamle Forest''': A forest area in [[Amphoe Chum Phuang]], [[Nakhon Ratchasima province]], it is similar to Submafai Forest case, one young man has been lost in the forest for five days in early September 2017. He claimed that he could find an exit by following a mysterious woman dressed in green Thai dress. Locals there are rumored to be this forest has a paranormal place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OixYg6CAuAQ|work=Channel 8|date=2017-09-10|accessdate=2017-11-20|language=thai|title=เจาะประเด็นข่าวเด่น วันที่ 11 กันยายน "เรื่องลี้ลับ หลงป่า ผีบังตา?"}}</ref> * '''Rural villages in Buriram''': [[Muban|Two villages]] in rural area of [[Amphoe Chamni]], [[Buriram province]]. The villagers are two women, one an 18-year-old teenager and another a 59-year-old woman, assert that they see flying cryptid, shaped like a big winged man in the night like [[Mothman]] or Ahool called ''[[Krahang]]'' in mid-July 2017. In particular, the 59-year-old woman said she had found it in her dreams for a long time, and she believed it came from a deserted house in the neighborhood. It is a house to one of her family once lived.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2k1unsvkhLI|title=ปรากฏการณ์ กระหัง-กระสือ (13 ก.ค.60)|date=2017-07-13|accessdate=2017-11-20|language=thai|work=Channel 3}}</ref> * '''[[Phanom Rung Historical Park]]''': A [[Khmer architecture|Khmer]] [[temple|rock temple]] complex set on the rim of an extinct volcano in Buriram province, founded since the 10th century to dedicate to the [[Shiva]], one of the [[Supreme Being|supreme gods]] of Hinduism. This place at night, it has been reported that people are exposed to harmful tall hungry ghost ''Preta''.<ref>{{IMDb title|1859750|"Destination Truth" Jungle Temple Ghosts/Namibian Night Stalker}}</ref>
==Southern== [[image:Ao Sunset, Koh Lipe (2007-03-321).jpg|thumb|Lipe Island]] [[File:Near Sarasin bridge - panoramio.jpg|thumb|fishing boats in Phuket, see the Sarasin Bridge behind]] * '''[[Ko Lipe|Lipe Island]]''': Located in the Andaman Sea, Lipe is inhabited by the Chao-Le, an ethnic group nicknamed the "Gypsies of the Andaman Sea". The Chao-Le have animist beliefs and say their island is full of rowdy spirits which they call ha-too. Tourists also claim feeling the presence of invisible forces during their stays there. Residents are said to be able to appease these spirits with offerings of cupcakes and cold strawberry soft drinks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/sweet-little-lipe-thailands-haunted-island-the-101740.html|title=Sweet Little Lipe: Thailand's Haunted Island in the Andaman Sea|work=[[Yahoo]]|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> * '''Wang Song Phi Nong Forest''': A forest area in Tambon Phichit, [[Amphoe Na Mom]], [[Songkhla province]]. In August 2017, a 38-year-old man lost in this forest for seven days. He said he saw people searching for him, but when he called no one hears. A medium claims that he has been hidden by the spirit of his wife [[reincarnation|in the previous life]]. That's surprising, even though he was lost for seven days. But his body isn't weak at all.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.khaosod.co.th/around-thailand/news_484009|title=หลอน! หนุ่มหลงป่า7วัน ทั้งที่ไม่ห่างบ้าน เห็นคนตามหา เดินวนรอบ แต่เรียกไม่ได้ยิน|date=2017-08-25|accessdate=2017-11-20|language=thai|work=Khao Sod}}</ref> * '''Sarasin Bridge''': The bridge between [[Phang Nga province]] and [[Phuket province]]. Is a place of the suicide of a young couple, an unloving lover on February 22, 1973. Locals are rumored that on the full moon night. There will a be a pair of white rabbits with red glowing eyes appearing on the bridge. Believed to be the soul of the couple.<ref>{{cite web|title=อกหักอย่าไป! 5 สถานที่ เห็นแล้วยิ่งเศร้า สะกิดแผลใจเจ็บแปลบ! |url= https://www.thairath.co.th/content/510281|date=2015-07-09|accessdate=2017-11-21|language=thai|work=Thairath}}</ref> * '''Chumphon Railway Bridge''': The railway bridge is part of the [[Southern Line (Thailand)|southern line]] in the area of [[Amphoe Pathio]], [[Chumphon province]]. There're many deaths at here, the locals called "Bridge 100 bodies". The story of it was broadcast on the popular paranormal TV program ''[[Khon Uad Phee]]'' in August 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hilight.kapook.com/view/90463|title=สะพานร้อยศพ จ.ชุมพร อาถรรพ์ทางรถไฟสยอง ในคนอวดผี|language=thai|date=2013-08-29|accessdate=2017-11-25|work=Kapook}}</ref> * '''[[Khao Lak]]''': Phang Nga's famous marine attraction in [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|late 2004 tsunami tragedy]], there are hundreds of deaths. And since then, the hotels in this zone became haunted hotel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://topicstock.pantip.com/blueplanet/topicstock/2012/09/E12600051/E12600051.html|title=โรงแรมไหนที่เขาหลักไม่มีผีคะ|language=thai|date=2012-09-02|accessdate=2017-11-25|work=Pantip.com|author= เฮ็ดอยู่อืดปืด}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Thai ghosts]] * [[List of reportedly haunted locations]] {{clear}}
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Judge | name = Louis Bennett Butler, Jr. | image = | imagesize = | caption = | office = | termstart = | termend = | nominator = | appointer = | predecessor = | successor = | office2 = Justice of the [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]] | term_start2 = August 2004 | term_end2 = July 31, 2008 | appointer2 = [[Jim Doyle]] | predecessor2 = | successor2 = [[Michael Gableman]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|2|15}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | death_date = | alma_mater = [[Lawrence University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[University of Wisconsin Law School]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) }} '''Louis Bennett Butler Jr.''' (born 1952) is a former justice of the [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]]. Butler was appointed to the Supreme Court by Governor [[Jim Doyle]] in August 2004; his term expired on July 31, 2008. He is the [[List of African American firsts|first]] [[African American]] to serve on the Wisconsin Supreme Court. Louis Butler was born and raised in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. He earned his bachelor's degree from [[Lawrence University]] in 1973 and his [[Juris Doctor|law degree]] from the [[University of Wisconsin Law School]] in 1977. After serving as an assistant state [[public defender]] from 1979 to 1992, Louis Butler was appointed to the [[State court (United States)|Municipal Court]] in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]]. He served as a municipal judge until 2002, when he was elected to Branch 9 of the [[Milwaukee County]] [[Circuit Court]]. Butler also served as an adjunct professor at [[Marquette University Law School]]. Butler campaigned for a seat on the Wisconsin Supreme Court in 2000, but lost his election bid to incumbent [[Diane Sykes]] by a wide margin. After being appointed to the Wisconsin Supreme Court in 2004, he was defeated by the Judge [[Michael Gableman]] in the April 1, 2008 elections. Butler was the first sitting Wisconsin Supreme Court justice to be defeated in a reelection campaign since 1967. The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' argued this loss stemmed from opinions he wrote in medical malpractice, search and seizure and product liability cases.{{cite web | last = Fund | first = John | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Wisconsin's Judicial Revolution | work = | publisher = ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' | date = 2008-04-05 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120735975782591721?mod=djemEditorialPage | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-05-27}} Business groups, including [[Wisconsin Manufacturers and Commerce]] (WMC), paid for a large number{{Clarify|date=December 2012}} of issue ads in this campaign cycle, although the Butler campaign outspent Gableman's by several hundred thousand dollars. {{cite journal |last=Basting |first=Thomas J. |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=President's Message: Gutter Politics and the Wisconsin Supreme Court |journal=Wisconsin Lawyer |volume=81 |issue=5 |pages= |publisher=wisbar.org |location=Madison, Wisconsin |date=May 2008 |url=http://www.wisbar.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&TEMPLATE=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=72127 |doi= |id= |accessdate=2008-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905035929/http://www.wisbar.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home |archivedate=2008-09-05 |df= }} Since his defeat, Butler agreed to serve a two-year term as Justice-in-Residence at the [[University of Wisconsin Law School]], where he would teach several courses and clinics for the 2008-2010 academic years.{{cite web | last = Chaptman | first = Dennis | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Former state Supreme Court justice to teach at UW Law School | work = | publisher = [[University of Wisconsin]] | date = 2008-09-24 | url = http://www.news.wisc.edu/15670 | format = | doi = | accessdate =2009-02-13}} On September 30, 2009, President [[Barack Obama]] nominated Butler to serve as [[United States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin]].{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Presidential-Nominations-sent-to-the-Senate-9/30/09/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012144511/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Presidential-Nominations-sent-to-the-Senate-9/30/09/ |archivedate=2009-10-12 |df= }} However, his nomination was returned to the President on December 24, 2009.https://www.senate.gov/pagelayout/legislative/one_item_and_teasers/nom_rtn.htm Obama renominated Butler on January 20, 2010, but the Senate returned the nomination to the President on August 5, 2010. Obama then renominated Butler on September 13, 2010. [[NPR]] commented on the Senate's reluctance to confirm Butler in an August 4, 2011 article, stating that "Some of the longest waiting nominees, Louis Butler of Wisconsin, [[Charles Bernard Day]] of Maryland and [[Edward C. DuMont|Edward Dumont]] of Washington happen to be black or openly gay".Carrie Johnson, ''[https://www.npr.org/2011/08/04/138903866/obama-gets-high-marks-for-diversifying-the-bench Obama Gets High Marks For Diversifying The Bench]'', [[NPR]] (August 4, 2011). His nomination was returned to the President on December 17, 2011, pursuant to the rules of the Senate.[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/B?r112:@FIELD%28FLD003+s%29+@FIELD%28DDATE+20111217%29 Senate Record for December 17, 2011] ==See also== * [[Barack Obama judicial appointment controversies]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Butler, Louis B.}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lawyers from Chicago]] [[Category:Lawrence University alumni]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin Law School alumni]] [[Category:African-American judges]] [[Category:American judges]] [[Category:Wisconsin state court judges]] [[Category:Wisconsin Supreme Court justices]] [[Category:Public defenders]]

Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Global distribution of mangroves" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Global distribution of mangroves}} {{term paper|date=September 2012}}
'''Global [[mangrove]] distributions''' have fluctuated throughout human and [[Geology|geological]] history. The area covered by mangroves is influenced by a complex interaction between land position, [[rain]]fall [[hydrology]], [[sea level]], [[sedimentation]], [[subsidence]], storms and pest-predator relationships<ref name="Eslami-Andargoli et al. 2009">Eslami-Andargoli, L., Dale, P. et al. (2009). "Mangrove expansion and rainfall patterns in Moreton Bay, Southeast Queensland, Australia." [[Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science]] 85(2): 292–298.</ref><ref>"McLeod and Salm 2006" McLeod, E. and R. V. Salm (2006). Managing mangroves for resilience to climate change. Gland, Switzerland, The World Conservation Union (IUCN) 2.</ref>). In the last 50 years, human activities have strongly affected mangrove distributions, resulting in declines or expansions of worldwide mangrove area. Mangroves provide several important ‘free services’ including [[coast]]al stabilization, [[juvenile fish]] habitats, and the filtration of sediment and nutrients<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001">Valiela, I., Bowen, J. L. & York, J. K. 2001. Mangrove forests: one of the world's threatened major tropical environments. BioScience, 51, 807–815.</ref><ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996">Dierberg, F. E. & Kiattisimkul, W. 1996. Issues, impacts, and implications of shrimp aquaculture in Thailand. Environmental Management, 20, 649-666.</ref><ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007">Morrisey, D., Beard, C., Morrison, M., Craggs, R. & Lowe, M. 2007. The New Zealand Mangrove: Review of the Current State Of Knowledge. Auckland Regional Council.</ref>). Mangrove loss has important implications for coastal [[Ecology|ecological]] systems and human communities dependent on healthy mangrove ecosystems. This [[English Wikipedia]] page presents an overview of global [[Mangrove|Mangrove Forest]] [[biome]] trends in [[:Category:Mangrove ecoregions|mangrove ecoregion]]s distribution, as well as the cause of such changes.
As of 2012, mangroves are found in 105 nations globally.<ref name=":0" /> Although distributed across 105 nations, the top 10 mangrove holding nations contain approximately 52% of the global mangrove stock with Indonesia alone containing between 26% and 29% of the entire global mangrove stock.<ref name=":0" /> The largest continuous area of mangrove forest is likely in-and-around the Sundarbans National Park in India and the Sundarbans Mangrove Forests in Bangladesh,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Global Mangrove Forests Distribution, v1: Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) {{!}} SEDAC|url=http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/lulc-global-mangrove-forests-distribution-2000|doi=10.7927/h4j67dw8}}</ref> which are both recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Sites.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/?search=sundarbans&searchSites=&search_by_country=&region=&search_yearinscribed=&themes=&criteria_restrication=&type=&media=&order=country&description=|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre - World Heritage List|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-10-21}}</ref> Although existing almost exclusively in the tropics and near-tropics, warm ocean currents support mangrove forests as far north as Walsingham Nature Reserve (Idwal Hughes Nature Reserve) in Bermuda and as far south as Snake Island, Australia.<ref name=":0" />
== Top 20 Mangrove Holdings Nations in 2012.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart E.|last2=Casey|first2=Daniel|date=2016-06-01|title=Creation of a high spatio-temporal resolution global database of continuous mangrove forest cover for the 21st century (CGMFC-21)|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/geb.12449/abstract|journal=Global Ecology and Biogeography|language=en|volume=25|issue=6|pages=729–738|doi=10.1111/geb.12449|issn=1466-8238}}</ref> ==
{| class="wikitable" |Rank |Country Name |Treecover in Mangrove Forests |Treecover in Wider Mangrove Biome |- | | |'''km2''' |'''km2''' |- |1 |Indonesia |23,324.29 |44,038.77 |- |2 |Brazil |7,674.94 |17,685.60 |- |3 |Malaysia |4,725.84 |8,231.09 |- |4 |Papua New Guinea |4,172.29 |5,677.16 |- |5 |Australia |3,316.21 |3,251.24 |- |6 |Mexico |2,991.83 |6,203.92 |- |7 |Myanmar |2,557.45 |3,856.09 |- |8 |Nigeria |2,653.99 |6,919.28 |- |9 |Venezuela |2,403.83 |7,539.12 |- |10 |Philippines |2,064.24 |2,089.24 |- |11 |Thailand |1,886.33 |4,196.97 |- |12 |Bangladesh |1,772.98 |2,314.56 |- |13 |Colombia |1,671.86 |6,274.70 |- |14 |Cuba |1,633.46 |2,454.10 |- |15 |United States |1,568.60 |1,585.06 |- |16 |Panama |1,323.94 |2,708.21 |- |17 |Mozambique |1,223.67 |2,677.27 |- |18 |Cameroon |1,112.76 |1,332.16 |- |19 |Gabon |1,082.11 |3,882.95 |- |20 |Ecuador |935.74 |1,945.27 |}
==Mangrove declines==
=== Global trends ===
In the last five decades, worldwide mangrove area has fallen across all regions.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Alongi 2002">Alongi, D. M. 2002. Present state and future of the world's mangrove forests. Environmental Conservation, 29, 331–349.</ref><ref name="FAO">FAO 2007. The World's Mangroves 1980–2005. FAO Forestry Paper. Rome: Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) no.153</ref> Different data sources or survey methods make estimates more problematic, as many nations have high variations of mangrove change.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001" /><ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="FAO" /><ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004">Barbier, E. & Sathirathai, S. 2004. Shrimp farming and mangrove loss in Thailand, Cheltenham, Edward Elgar Publishing.</ref>
'''Percentage of original area lost per year''' * Asia: 1.52% * Africa: 1.25% * Australia: 1.99% * Americas: 3.62% * The World: 2.07%
(based on data from)<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/> ''(Annual loss rates calculated from the mean number of years between original area and present area for each region: 24, 25, 7, 11, and 17 years for Asia, Africa, Australia, the Americas, and the world, respectively.) ''
From 2000 to 2012, the global mangrove deforestation rate was between 0.16% and 0.39% annually but as high as 3.58% to 8.08% in Southeast Asia.<ref name=":0"/> The most recent and comprehensive global assessment of mangrove distribution was conducted by Hamilton and Casey (2016) and provides a high-resolution global database of mangrove loss at the 1 arc-second level at annual intervals from 2000 to 2012 with estimates for 2013 and 2014.<ref name=":0"/> In the 1980s and 1990s the greatest amount of loss occurred, while in the period of 2000 to 2005 the rate has fallen significantly across all regions.<ref name="FAO"/> Some projections estimate that worldwide mangrove area will decline by a further 25% by 2025, particularly in developing nations.<ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006">McLeod, E. & Salm, R. V. 2006. Managing mangroves for resilience to climate change. Gland, Switzerland: The World Conservation Union (IUCN)</ref> It is estimated that since 1970, 28% of mangrove lost has been directly displaced by commercial aquaculture.<ref name="Hamilton 585–601">{{Cite journal|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart|date=2013-04-01|title=Assessing the Role of Commercial Aquaculture in Displacing Mangrove Forest|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/umrsmas/bullmar/2013/00000089/00000002/art00013|journal=Bulletin of Marine Science|volume=89|issue=2|pages=585–601|doi=10.5343/bms.2012.1069}}</ref>
===Role of perception=== People’s [[perception]] of mangrove ecosystems has been instrumental in the loss of mangroves. Commonly, they have been undervalued and considered ‘wastelands’ with low [[productivity]] (,<ref name="FAO"/><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/><ref name="Krauss et al. 2008">Krauss, K. W., Lovelock, C. E., McKee, K. L., Lopez-Hoffman, L., Ewe, S. M. L. & Sousa, W. P. 2008. Environmental drivers in mangrove establishment and early development: A review. Aquatic Botany, 89, 105–127.</ref>). Concerns for the fate of mangroves have historically been restricted to [[Scientific community|scientific communities]], with little transfer of knowledge to [[Local community|local communities]] and governments.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/> Mangroves are a [[Common-pool resource|common pool resource]], creating difficulties in enforcing restrictions on exploitative activities.<ref name="Idrus 2009">Idrus, M. R. 2009. Hard habits to break : investigating coastal resource utilisations and management systems in Sulawesi, Indonesia : a thesis submitted in partial of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in Environmental Science at the University of Canterbury.</ref> More recently, perceptions have shifted to a broader acknowledgment within communities and governments of the value of mangroves in coastal ecosystems and local communities. The declining rate of mangrove loss since 2000 across all regions is indicative of this, bringing forth an increasing number of [[Conservation biology|conservation]] projects and [[legislation]].<ref name="FAO"/>
===Causes of decline=== A variety of factors have led to the declining trends in mangrove distribution (refer to table fig of causes). These factors are predominantly [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] in origin, as mangrove destruction is positively [[Correlation and dependence|correlated]] to human population density.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /> Up to 35% of mangrove forests worldwide have been lost since 1980, reflecting the increased pressure from high population densities residing at the [[coast]].<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="FAO"/> Mangrove losses to climate change are considered a probable long term threat to future distribution.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/> Despite a wide variety of factors linked to mangrove loss (insert figure of causes), the main drivers of recent (i.e. after 1980) mangrove destruction are linked to four main activities: [[urban sprawl]], [[tourism]], [[agriculture]] and [[aquaculture]].<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997">Farnsworth, E. J. & Ellison, A. M. 1997. The global conservation status of mangroves. Ambio, 328–334.</ref> The causes of declines in mangrove areas vary between regions. In [[Asia]], the [[Caribbean]] and [[Latin America]], aquaculture and tourism development are the greatest threat.<ref name="FAO"/> In [[Oceania]], tourism development is the greatest threat while in [[Africa]], conversion of mangroves for agricultural and urban development is most apparent.<ref name="FAO"/>
'''Aquaculture''' – This activity is considered the greatest contributor to worldwide mangrove loss.<ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006" /><ref name="Hamilton 585–601"/> Since the 1980s, [[shrimp]] aquaculture dramatically increased, replacing mangroves with ponds and degrading surrounding areas with associated pollution.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001" /><ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /><ref name="FAO" /> Aquaculture has dramatically affected some regions. For example, 50-80% of mangroves were lost in Asia in the past decades.<ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997" /> Asia, the Caribbean and Latin America have been most affected by aquaculture<ref name="FAO" />
[[File:Lone house in Petite-Anse (1180932461).jpg|thumb|Urban expansion - Urban development on mangrove habitat in [[Cap-Haitien, Haiti]]]]
'''Urban expansion''' – As population density increases at the coast, areas of mangrove forest have been replaced to provide urban and [[Industry|industrial]] lands.<ref name="FAO"/>
'''Tourism''' – infrastructure supporting tourism often requires the reclamation of substantial tracts of mangrove forests.<ref name="FAO"/> In the Americas and Oceania, tourism is a major driver of mangrove loss. Where tourism is a main contributor to an [[economy]] (such as Pacific Island nations), construction of [[resort]]s and related [[infrastructure]]s have reduced mangrove area in past decades.<ref name="FAO"/>
'''Agriculture''' – Conversion of mangrove forests for agriculture has occurred across all regions historically, freeing up land for activities such as rice or [[salt]] production (.<ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/>
[[File:ShrimpFarming Honduras L7 1987-99.jpg|thumb| Shrimp farming development in Honduras. Lower image is before devopment in 1987, upeer image is following expansion of ponds in 1999]]
====Mangrove loss case study: shrimp aquaculture in South-east Asia==== In many South-east Asian nations, shrimp aquaculture has been instrumental in mangrove loss, particularly in the 1980s and 1990s.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /><ref name="FAO"/> Due to high economic returns, shrimp farming was promoted to improve economic conditions in many countries.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /><ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /> The social and economic benefits of shrimp farming are substantial.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /> Shrimp farms are located close to the coast to reduce costs by using [[Tide|tidal]] energy and short [[canal]] lengths to the coast.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /> Consequently, vast tracts of mangrove forest have been replaced by numerous ponds. Compounding mangrove losses is the short life span of individual ponds (5–10 years), imposing a [[shifting cultivation]] pattern to shrimp farming.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/>
After 1980, shrimp farming became far more [[intensive]], with high productivity (per unit area) ponds proliferating across the landscape.<ref name="Dierbergand and Kiattisimkul 1996" /> Dramatic reductions in mangrove forests were reported with shrimp pond intensification. In [[Thailand]], mangrove forests literally halved between 1975–1993<ref name="Aksornkoae and Tokrishna 2004">Aksornkoae, S. & Tokrishna, R. 2004. Overview of shrimp farming and mangrove loss in Thailand. In: Barbier, E. & Sathirathai, S. (eds.) Shrimp farming and mangrove loss in Thailand. Cheltenham Edward Elgar Publishing.</ref> The impact of such losses has been linked to the disruption of [[Ecology|ecological]] and economic functioning of mangroves.<ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /> For example, loss of income for local Thai fishermen has been reported due to reduced catches from the degradation of [[Juvenile (organism)|juvenile]] fish habitat.<ref name="Barbier and Sathirathai 2004" /><ref name="Aksornkoae and Tokrishna 2004" /> Some consider that the number of shrimp farms in South-east Asia peaked in the late 1990s, with the rate of mangrove loss declining accordingly.<ref name="Aksornkoae and Tokrishna 2004" /> This decline is in part due to increased [[Conservation biology|conservation]] and [[Restoration ecology|restoration]] projects, and improved [[management]] practices.
===Global climate change and mangrove loss=== Increases in temperature, CO2, precipitation, storms, and sea level are likely to threaten mangroves in the future.<ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/> Sea level rise is considered the greatest [[climate change]] related threat to mangrove regions.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="McLeod and Salm 2006"/> The natural ability of mangroves to ‘keep up’ with rising [[sea level]] through [[peat]] or [[sediment]] accumulation could be exceeded, leading to mangrove die back.<ref name="Ellison 1993">Ellison, J. C. 1993. Mangrove retreat with rising sea-level, Bermuda. [[Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science]], 37, 75–87.</ref>[[Low island]] mangroves are most at risk, as demonstrated in [[Bermuda]], where sea level rise has exceeded peat accumulation rates periodically, resulting in landward die back of mangrove stands.<ref name="Ellison 1993" /> Climate change may reduce global mangrove area by 10-15%, but it is a long term, less significance threat to the current 1-2% annual loss from human activities.<ref name="Alongi 2002" />
==Mangrove expansions==
=== Global trends ===
Several nations have experienced an expansion of their mangrove area. These expansions include human activities promoting seaward or landward expansion from climatic or other local factors, as well as conservation and [[reforestation]] programmes.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Saintilan and Wilton 2001" /> Globally, this stability and expansion is far outweighed by the magnitude of mangrove loss from human activities.
===Seaward expansion and human activity=== Seaward mangrove expansion is considered a natural response to high inputs of sediment and nutrients from human activity in adjacent [[Catchment area (human geography)|catchments]];.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Harty 2009">Harty, C. 2009. Mangrove planning and management in New Zealand and South East Australia - A reflection on approaches. Ocean and Coastal Management, 52, 278–286.</ref><ref name="Lovelock et al 2007">Lovelock, C. E., Feller, I. C., Ellis, J., Schwarz, A. M., Hancock, N., Nichols, P. & Sorrell, B. 2007. Mangrove growth in New Zealand estuaries: The role of nutrient enrichment at sites with contrasting rates of sedimentation.</ref> Mangroves naturally encourage [[sediment]] deposition by slowing [[Ocean current|currents]] and attenuating [[Wind wave|waves]]. However, with high [[sediment]] inputs, the elevation of [[intertidal]] flats can rise above the [[low tide]] limit of the original mangrove forest, resulting in a seaward expansion of new mangrove [[habitat]].<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /> Once new mangroves establish, they too begin to trap more sediment, raising the tidal flat elevation and generating more mangrove habitat.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /> Seaward expansions are likely in regions with modified catchments (i.e. deforestation or urban development) with high topography where high sediments loads are delivered to mangroves at the coast.<ref name="Harty 2009" /> Extremely high rates of sediment input can exceed tolerance thresholds and induce mangrove die backs.<ref name="Krauss et al. 2008"/> Excess sedimentation is the primary control, but [[nutrients]] (i.e. from [[agricultural runoff]]) can enhance mangrove expansion, particularly when combined with high levels of [[sedimentation]].<ref name="Lovelock et al 2007" /> Seaward expansions highlight the interconnectivity of mangrove ecosystems to adjacent catchments and the need to consider catchment alteration when managing mangroves.
[[File:SEAWARD mangrove migration.jpg|thumb| Conceptual model of seaward mangrove migrations]]
====Case study: New Zealand mangroves==== In [[New Zealand]] (NZ), [[temperate]] mangroves (Avicennia marina) are common in [[estuaries]], harbours and [[tidal]] creeks north of 38° latitude.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /> Following [[European colonization]], mangrove area declined, but since the 1970s rapid, ongoing seaward expansion has occurred in many areas.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Lovelock et al 2007" /><ref name="Park 2004">Park, S. 2004. Aspects of Mangrove Distribution and Abundance in Tauranga Harbour. Whakatane: Environment Bay of Plenty, 2004/16.</ref> For example, in the last 50 years mangrove area has expanded 120% in Tuaranga Harbour.<ref name="Park 2004" /> Such expansion is strongly correlated with elevated rates of sediment deposition. [[Drainage basin|Catchment]] activities such as [[deforestation]] and more recently, [[urban development]] have been blamed for the expansion.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Lovelock et al 2007" /><ref name="Park 2004" /> Considerable debate over whether to protect or remove NZ mangroves exist. Proponents for protection cite the ecological and coastal protection values of mangrove stands, while removal advocates aim to restore recreational values and prevent encroachment into non-mangrove ecosystems.<ref name="Harty 2009" /> A shift in the management strategy of regional councils from protection to mangrove ‘management’ has occurred recently<ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="De Luca 2009">De Luca, S. 2009. Mangrove Management - Balancing Values. Coastal News, NZ no. 42.</ref> Removals may take place when human amenities or non-mangrove habitats are deemed threatened by mangrove encroachment.<ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="De Luca 2009" /> Some researchers caution comparisons being made between NZ and [[tropical]] mangroves, suggesting NZ mangroves are unique in their ecology and require a tailored [[management]] approach.<ref name="Harty 2009" />
===Landward expansion=== In contrast to seaward expansions in NZ, [[landward]] expansions are documented in a number of regions ([[Thailand]], Australia, and [[Hawaii]]).<ref name="Eslami-Andargoli et al. 2009" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Saintilan and Wilton 2001">Saintilan, N. & Wilton, K. 2001. Changes in the distribution of mangroves and saltmarshes in Jervis Bay, Australia. Wetlands Ecology and Management, 9, 409–420.</ref><ref name="Chimner et al. 2006">Chimner, R. A., Fry, B., Kaneshiro, M. Y. & Cormier, N. 2006. Current Extent and Historical Expansion of Introduced Mangroves on O'ahu, Hawai'i1. Pacific Science, 60, 377–383</ref> The cause of landward expansions is not always clear. In Eastern Australia expansions have replaced salt marshes with various suggestions for the cause of landward expansion (increased rainfall, changes in hydrology, to local subsidence).<ref name="Eslami-Andargoli et al. 2009" /><ref name="Harty 2009" /><ref name="Saintilan and Wilton 2001" /> Expansions in Hawaii are thought to be the result of invasions by [[Invasive species|exotic]] mangrove species.<ref name="Chimner et al. 2006" />
===Expansion through conservation and restoration=== More recently, awareness of the economic, social, and [[ecological]] values of mangroves have led to an increase in the number of initiatives to protect and restore mangrove areas.<ref name="Valieala et al. 2001"/><ref name="FAO"/> Broader recognition of the connection of mangroves to coastal food chains, [[coastal protection]] and [[socio-economic]] welfare has driven recent conservation.<ref name="FAO"/> For example, [[Bangladesh]] has undertaken extensive coastal afforesation (mass plantings) projects since 1966, leading to an increase in mangrove area in recent decades;<ref name="FAO"/><ref name="Saenger N. A. 1993">Saenger, N. A. 1993. Land from the sea: the mangrove afforestation program of Bangladesh. Ocean & Coastal Management, 20, 23–39</ref> 2005;.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /> Many nations with mangroves have signed on to the 1971 [[Ramsar Convention]] on wetlands in the last two decades, making a commitment to [[wetland]] preservation.<ref name="Ramsar 1971">Ramsar. 1971. Ramsar Convention on Wetlands [Online]. Available: http://www.ramsar.org/cda/en/ramsar-about-about-ramsar/main/ramsar/1-36%5E7687_4000_0__ [Accessed April 2010].</ref> However, the adoption of protective [[legislation]] is not evenly spread. For instance, community initiatives to protect mangroves are common in Africa but little legislation exists compared to other regions, such as Asia.<ref name="FAO"/>
==Challenges, limitations and future suggestions== Much attention has been given to mangroves by the [[scientific community]], as well as a largely universal acknowledgement among communities and governments of the ecological and economic values.<ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/> Despite this awareness, global mangrove area continues to decline through human activities. A lack of communication between [[biologists]], effected residents, and governments could partly account for this.<ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/> Calls have been made for greater [[collaboration]] between international researchers and residents of affected nations. Efforts to assess changes in worldwide mangrove distribution have been hindered by a lack of long term data, or limited to no data at all for some nations.<ref name="Alongi 2002" /><ref name="Farnsworth and Ellison 1997"/> Without accurate data on distributions, an accurate forecast of mangrove loss or expansion becomes problematic. This in turn may hinder the progress of [[Conservation biology|conservation]] projects. Despite large volumes of [[scientific literature]] on [[mangroves]], many uncertainties still exist. These include how mangroves will respond to increases in greenhouse gases and sea level, [[sustainable]] yields for silviculture, the difference in ecological functioning between tropical and [[temperate]] species, and why within the same species we get seaward and landward expansions.<ref name="Morrisey et al. 2007" /><ref name="Alongi 2002" /> Obtaining this knowledge will help nations to better predict future mangrove behavior, and administer appropriate [[management]] policies.
==Summary== Mangrove loss has been a worldwide trend for the last 50 years due primarily to [[human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] activities that compete for land area. Expansions in mangrove area do occur, but have a limited ability to offset the extensive losses. Recently the rate of loss has been declining due to a greater awareness of mangrove values, with legislation and conservation projects becoming more commonplace. It can only be hoped that this declining rate of loss continues, allowing future generations to appreciate the many benefits of mangroves.
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Mangrove]] - ''Mangrove Forest biome'' * [[:Category:Mangrove ecoregions|Mangrove ecoregions]] * [[Ecological values of mangrove]] * [[Coastal biogeomorphology]] * [[Coastal erosion]] {{col-end}}
==References==
{{Reflist|26em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mangrove tree distribution}} [[Category:Mangroves|*]] [[Category:Aquatic ecology]] [[Category:Climate change]] [[Category:Mangrove ecoregions|*]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox judge | honorific-prefix = | name = Marcia Gail Cooke | honorific-suffix = | image = | alt = | caption = | office = Judge of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida]] | term_start = May 18, 2004 | term_end = | nominator = | appointer = [[List of federal judges appointed by George W. Bush|George W. Bush]] | predecessor = [[Wilkie D. Ferguson]] | successor = | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1954}} | birth_place = [[Sumter, South Carolina|Sumter]], [[South Carolina]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship = | nationality = | party = | otherparty = | height = | spouse = | partner = | relations = | children = | parents = | mother = | father = | relatives = | residence = | education = {{nowrap|[[Georgetown University]] ([[School of Foreign Service|B.S.F.S.]])}}
[[Wayne State University Law School]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | known_for = | salary = | net_worth = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Marcia Gail Cooke''' (born 1954) is an [[Law of the United States|American lawyer]] and [[United States federal judge|United States District Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida]]. ==Early life and education== Cooke was born in 1954 in [[Sumter, South Carolina|Sumter]], [[South Carolina]]. She graduated from the [[Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service]] at [[Georgetown University]] with a [[School of Foreign Service|Bachelor of Science in Foreign Service]] in 1975 and from [[Wayne State University Law School]] with a [[Juris Doctor]] in 1977. ==Legal career== Cooke was a staff attorney for Neighborhood Legal Services in [[Michigan]] from 1978 to 1979 and was a deputy [[public defender]] of the Legal Aid and Defender Association in Michigan from 1979-1980. Cooke served as an [[United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan|Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan]] from 1980 to 1983. From 1983 to 1984 Cooke was in private practice in Michigan with the [[Law firm|firm]] of Miro, Miro and Weiner. Cooke served as a [[United States Magistrate Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan]] from 1984 to 1992. In 1992 Cooke served as director of [[professional development]] and training at the [[United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida|U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida]]. From 1992 to 1994 she was the Executive Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, before returning to her director of professional development and training from 1994 to 1999. Cooke served as chief [[inspector general]] for the [[Governor of Florida|Executive Office of the Governor of Florida]] under [[Jeb Bush]] from 1999 to 2002. From 2002 to 2004 she was assistant [[county attorney]] in [[Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]]. ==Federal judicial career== [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] nominated Cooke to the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida]] on November 25, 2003, to the seat vacated by [[Wilkie D. Ferguson]]. She was [[Advice and consent|confirmed]] by the [[United States Senate|Senate]] on May 18, 2004, Cooke received her [[Letters patent|commission]] the same day. She is the first [[Black people|black]] woman [[United States federal judge|federal judge]] in [[Florida]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2004-06-08-federal-judge_x.htm|title=USATODAY.com - First black woman federal judge in Florida sworn in|publisher=}} Cooke presided over the trial of [[José Padilla (prisoner)|José Padilla]] in 2007. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *{{FJC Bio|nid=1392101}} {{s-start}} {{s-legal}} {{s-bef|before=[[Wilkie D. Ferguson]]}} {{s-ttl|title={{nowrap|Judge of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida]]}}|years=2004–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{United States 11th Circuit district judges}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cooke, Marcia Gail}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:African-American judges]] [[Category:African-American women lawyers]] [[Category:American women lawyers]] [[Category:African-American lawyers]] [[Category:American women judges]] [[Category:Assistant United States Attorneys]] [[Category:Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service alumni]] [[Category:Judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida]] [[Category:Michigan lawyers]] [[Category:People from Sumter, South Carolina]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:United States district court judges appointed by George W. Bush]] [[Category:21st-century American judges]] [[Category:United States magistrate judges]] [[Category:Wayne State University Law School alumni]]
